title: Provide a way for Gaffer graphs to be migrated/versioned
body:
Currently Gaffer doesn't really handle migrating and versioning, you need to handle this yourself. You are able to add new properties, change aggregators and in HBase/Accumulo you can rename properties in the schema. Other changes such as removing/reordering properties, changing serialisers or property types, renaming groups is difficult to do and we don't currently provide any help for doing this.

For large graphs it may not be possible/feasible to attempt to migrate all your data so we should provide the ability for a new version of the schema to be used and allow queries to be automatically adapted to run against the new and the old data, aggregating the results.

It would be nice if we could provide an automated way to handle migrations or at least some documentation explaining how we suggest it should be done.

### Some thoughts

If you simply want to change the type of a property:

Schema v1 (the current schema):
```
BasicEdge
  - property1 (int)
```

Schema v2 (the new schema):
```
BasicEdge
 - property1 (long)
```

 The idea would be that Gaffer would merge these schemas together to form something like:
```
BasicEdge
 - property1 (in)

BasicEdge|2
 - property1 (long)
```

Ingesters would need to be updated to start populating BasicEdge|2 instead of the original BasicEdge group.

When a query is executed, it now needs to be adapted to query for both BasicEdge and BasicEdge|2 and we need to apply a conversion to allow these 2 different types of edges to be merged together. This conversion should be supplied by a sys admin, in the form of a mapping json file, detailing how the migration from version1 to version 2 should be carried out. In this case a a transform function that casts an int into a long would be sufficient. More complex migrations that involve new properties, deleting properties could be carried out in a similar way.

If the Graph is configured to age data off after a period of time, then after some time when all the BasicEdge edges have been deleted, this migration can be removed and users would be able to query directly for the new EdgeGroup|2 group.

This process would have an impact on performance as we would need to aggregate the BasicEdge edges with BasicEdge|2 edges at query time. This could be pushed down to Accumulo, but that could be optimised later in a separate issue.

I think this mapping could all be done via a GraphHook. The difficulty would be working out which predicates could be pushed down to Accumulo and which ones have to be done after the extra query time migration aggregation is carried out. 
This could be something like:
- Leave the PreAggFilters as they are 
- PostAggFilters, Transforms and PostTransformFilters would need to be 'deleted'. 
- Run the query
- Apply any extra migration aggregation that is required
- Then apply the original PostAggFilters, Transforms and PostTransformFilters.

The above logic could be skipped if the query doesn't contain any groups that have been migration.

Converter should be used to get group from key in AccumuloStore
body:
This is similar to #1535.

In `AggregatorIterator` in the Accumulo store, the group is obtained from the key using

    group = new String(key.getColumnFamilyData().getBackingArray(), CommonConstants.UTF_8)

This should be done by using the `elementConverter`.

The group is obtained from the key in the `getEdgeFromKey` method in `AbstractCoreKeyAccumuloElementConverter` using the same approach. It should use the `getGroupFromKey` method (this reduces code duplication and allows concrete key classes to override the method of obtaining the key).

title: GetWalks operation results in exception if a hop contains no results
body:
Example ```OperationChain```:

```java
final OperationChain<Iterable<Walk>> opChain = new OperationChain.Builder()
                .first(new GetWalks.Builder()
                        .operations(
                                new OperationChain.Builder()
                                        .first(new GetElements.Builder()
                                                .view(new View.Builder()
                                                        .edges(Lists.newArrayList("edge", "edge1"))
                                                        .build())
                                                .inOutType(SeededGraphFilters.IncludeIncomingOutgoingType.INCOMING)
                                                .build())
                                        .then(new Sort.Builder()
                                                .comparators(new ElementPropertyComparator.Builder()
                                                        .property("count")
                                                        .build())
                                                .build())
                                        .build(),
                                new OperationChain.Builder()
                                        .first(new GetElements.Builder()
                                                .view(new View.Builder()
                                                        .entity("entity1", new ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
                                                                .preAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
                                                                        .select("count")
                                                                        .execute(new IsMoreThan(10000))
                                                                        .build())
                                                                .build())
                                                        .build())
                                                .build())
                                        .then(new GetElements.Builder()
                                                .view(new View.Builder()
                                                        .edge("edge1")
                                                        .build())
                                                .inOutType(SeededGraphFilters.IncludeIncomingOutgoingType.INCOMING)
                                                .build())
                                        .build())
                        .input(new EntitySeed(5))
                        .build())
                .build();
```

If the preAggregationFilter leads to no results being returned no AdjacencyMap is registered by the GetWalksHandler. This leads to a mismatch between the number of expected hops and the number of recorded hops.

I don't think it is worth trying to define all the properties in the annotation, just the important ones, then sort the others alphabetically.

For example:

GetElements: @JsonPropertyOrder(value = {"class", "input", "view"}, alphabetic = true)

Edge: @JsonPropertyOrder(
        value = {"class", "group", "source", "destination", "directed", "matchedVertex", "properties"},
        alphabetic = true)

Entity: @JsonPropertyOrder(value = {"class", "group", "vertex", "properties"},  alphabetic = true)

@JsonPropertyOrder(value = {"class"}, alphabetic = true)

Gh 1507 graphframe element generator
body:
Initial ideas for converting a GraphFrame (or a DataFrame) to an Iterable of Element objects. The implementation here uses two operations to achieve this:

* GraphFrameToIterable
* GenerateElements (with a RowToElementGenerator)

Unfortunately it's not straightforward to use a generator as is, since the bulk of the generators in Gaffer at the moment are geared up for converting Iterable<OBJ> -> Iterable<Element>. So in order to use the existing generator-based approach, the GraphFrame must be first converted into an Iterable<Row>.

There are a few caveats here based on some limitations of the use of DataFrames:

* All elements are pulled into a single DataFrame/GraphFrame, so it will not always be possible to distinguish between edge properties and entity properties. If an edge group and an entity group are present that share a property name, it will not always be possible to reconstruct the original elements - these properties must be of the same type (this is noted in the AccumuloStoreRelation javadoc).
* The implementation relies on the use of several reserved words (src, dst, id, vertex etc). If any of these words are used as property names, then this approach will not work.

Any suggestions would be welcome - should we stick with using a Generator approach or shall I wrap these into a single operation?

This should be merged after gh-1436.

title: HBase store deduplicates elements that have the same key and timestamp
body:
The HBase store will normally default this value for you to the current system time in milliseconds.
If you add 2 elements within the same millisecond that have the same Key then the elements will be deduplicated.

This can also happen if you have set the "timestampProperty" field in your schema and you manually populate the timestamp property yourself. You would need to ensure the timestamps are different.

This bug is caused by the versioning iterator in HBase deduplicating the elements. In Accumulo, we are able to disable the versioning iterator so we don't have this problem.

To solve this we recommend you don't populate the timestamp field yourself and let the HBase store do it for you. Rather than just defaulting it to the current time we will add an element of randomness to the value. This will mean the timestamp value will no longer represent time, it will just be a random number.

title: Visibilities lost when doing AddElementsFromHdfs in HBase

title: AddElementsFromHdfs deduplicates Elements that have aggregation disabled and identical keys
body:
Hi again,

I'm still looking at the netflow data I've mentioned in other questions. I specified in the schema that Netflow edges are not to be aggregated and each edge represents a single netflow event in the original csv with probably different properties.

When I use the startTime property as the timestamp (I have to nano precision, but storing at millis), only one record is stored in accumulo even if I have >1 record with the same source+destination+timestamp. I've also tried using the default timestamp and this is resulting in more missing records. I've checked the element generator, and all the elements are being generated correctly.

Here is some example records from the CTU13 dataset (previously mentioned) that demonstrates the problem.
These two records have the same source (::) and destination (ff02::1:ff97:a3eb), and the timestamps both map to 2011/08/12 15:59:53.173 (converted to a long), and only the first one was in accumulo
```
[2011/08/12 15:59:53.173326,0.0,ipv6-icmp,::,130,   ->,ff02::1:ff97:a3eb,null,MRQ,0,null,1,86,86,flow=Background]
[2011/08/12 15:59:53.173341,90.500267,ipv6-icmp,::,135,   ->,ff02::1:ff97:a3eb,null,NNS,0,null,6,468,468,flow=Background]
```
These two records have the same source (::) and destination (ff02::1:ff9d:312f), and the timestamps map to different values: 2011/08/12 16:09:48.275 and 2011/08/12 16:09:48.276, and both records are in accumulo
```
[2011/08/12 16:09:48.275895,0.500047,ipv6-icmp,::,135,   ->,ff02::1:ff9d:312f,null,NNS,0,null,2,156,156,flow=Background]
[2011/08/12 16:09:48.276904,0.0,ipv6-icmp,::,130,   ->,ff02::1:ff9d:312f,null,MRQ,0,null,1,86,86,flow=Background]
```

Do you have any suggestions about how I can change my config / ingest to ensure that all my events are stored separately?

Thanks,
Amanda

/graph/operations/{className} should only return information about registered classes
body:
There was a debate when we first wrote this end point about what the method should do, but I think the currently implementation is misleading.

Currently /graph/operations/{className} returns details about operations that are on the class path but not registered in the store. 
/graph/operations returns only operations that are registered in the store, so I think /graph/operations/{className} should do the same.

title: Releasing 1.1.0-RC1
Create GetShortestPath operation
body:
The GetShortestPath should take a start and end vertex (should it be an EntitySeed or just the vertex value?)

It should be configured with a maximum number of hops.

It would be useful for users to be able to specify which edge groups they wanted to traverse along. Users may also want to apply filters to those edges, or filter based on Entities. It is best to follow a similar pattern to GetWalks, where users provide a list of GetElements operations relating to the types of edges they want to traverse along?

What do we mean by shortest? The fewest number of edges? Or perhaps we use some number property like count on each edge and we find the path that has the smallest total count? A nice way to solve this question would be to allow a Function to be provided that takes a list of edges and returns the score. This could be defaulted to a Function that simply returns the length of the list.

title: The Flink GafferSink add elements queue could run out of memory
body:
The implementation of `AddElementsFromKafkaHandler` that uses Flink to add data from Kafka contains some code that looks unnecessarily complicated and there's no Javadoc to explain why it's done this way:

- The `invoke` method on `GafferSink` receives an `Iterable` of `Element`s. This will normally be a small batch of `Element`s created from a single Kafka entry. Presumably this is passed to a `GafferSink` which passes it to a `GafferAdder` to avoid the expense of creating an `AddElements` operation for each small batch. If a `flatMap` was called after the `map` in `doOperation` in `AddElementsFromKafkaHandler` then the sink would receive a never-ending iterable of elements which could be passed to a single `AddElement`s operation - only one of these would ever need to be created. There would be no need for a `GafferAdder`.
- The `GafferAdder` maintains a `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` of elements. It looks like it's assumed that elements will be continually added to the queue whilst the `AddElements` operation is simultaneously running and pulling data from it. This means that if the `AddElements` operation is slower than the ingest from Kafka (e.g. because Accumulo is under load) then it will eventually run out of memory, i.e. there is no way of back pressure being applied to earlier functions in the stream. There should be a test to check that back pressure is applied.

If the design is correct then there should be some Javadoc to explain why it's done this way.

Marked as a possible bug in case the OOM issue is true.

title: SplitStore from Iterable of Elements
body:
The only way of adding split points to an Accumulo table is to use `SampleDataForSplitPoints` followed by `SplitStore`. This is difficult to use if the source data is only available as an iterable, e.g. if it's on Kafka.

We should create a way for a user to create some split points based on an iterable of elements.

title: Improve GetDataframeOfElementsHandler for Parquet store
body:
The `GetDataframeOfElementsHandler` for the Parquet store doesn't take advantage of the partitioning and sorting. This means that a query such as "select * where vertex=A" has to read a lot more data than is necessary.

The Accumulo store already does this: it uses `GetRDDOfAllElements` if the query can't take advantage of the sorting, but a `GetRDDOfElements` with appropriate vertices if it can.

The approach for the Parquet store should be able to take advantage of some of the code for the Accumulo store.

title: Improved approach to loading data into Parquet store from Accumulo store
body:
Data can currently be loaded from an Accumulo store into a Parquet store by using a `GetRDDOfAllElements` operation followed by an `ImportRDDOfElements` operation. This approach does not take advantage of the sorting of the Accumulo data. The elements are written out to a temporary directory, and then resorted.

It would be better to take each Accumulo tablet and write that out as sorted Parquet files. Each tablet contains 3 types of key-value corresponding to Entitys, "forward" edges and "backwards" edges. These would be written out to different Parquet files (under the group=G/ directories for entities and forwards edges or under the sorted-by-destination directory for backwards edges). These files would already be sorted and partitioned. This should significantly speed up ingest into the Parquet store from the Accumulo store. The resulting files may not be uniformly sized, e.g. if there is an Accumulo tablet containing only edges out of a single high-degree vertex, but this is probably a trade worth making if the ingest time is improved.

This approach should take advantage of the option to directly read RFiles in `GetRDDOfAllElements` as this means the export can be done without imposing additional load on Accumulo's tablet servers.

title: New Accumulo key-package optimised for `GetRDDOfAllElements`
body:
The `GetRDDOfAllElements` operation applies a filter to avoid every `Edge` being returned twice. This means that twice as many `Edge`s as necessary are being read. This could be avoided by storing the "forward" version of an `Edge` of group G with one column family (e.g. "G-F") and the "backwards" version with a different column family (e.g. "G-B"). As long as there is one locality group for each of these then this will reduce the amount of data read by a `GetRDDOfAllElements` operation by a factor of 2.

This could also improve the efficiency of some other queries and possibly slightly slow down others.

This needs a new key-package.

Gh 1381 time series property
Create Operations interface for an Operation that has nested Operations
body:
Currently the only operation that has nested operations is OperationChain. However, in the future there may be more like Path #1301.

In Graph and GraphHooks we do various processing that recursively applies logic to all operations. If the operation has nested operations then we also need to apply the logic to those operations too. At the moment we do a check if(op instanceof OperationChain) then apply the logic to all nested operations.

To allow for operations like Path in the future we should create an interface like:

interface Operations<OP extends Operation> {
      Collection< OP> getOperations();
}

Then OperationChain and Path can implement this interface.

Throughout the code where we recursively look up nested operations we can now check if the Operation is an instance of Operations instead of using OperationChain. The main places in the code base to update are:
- AddOperationsToChain.addOperationsToChain
- Graph.updateOperationChainView
please do a global search for "instanceof OperationChain" and check whether each one needs to be updated too.

title: Add a /properties endpoint to the REST API
body:
This should allow a predefined set of properties/configuration to be exposed.

GET /properties should return a map of all exposed property key values.
GET /properties/{name} should return the value of the property with the given name.

The set of exposed properties should be configured in rest.properties. E.g
```properties
gaffer.properties=gaffer.properties.app-description,some-other-property
gaffer.properties.app-description="This is a description about the this application"
gaffer.properties.some-other-property="This is some other property"
gaffer.properties.some-hidden-property="This is some other hidden property"
```

So /properties would return:
```json
{
"gaffer.properties.app-description": "This is a description about the this application",
"gaffer.properties.some-other-property": "This is some other property",
}
```

/properties/gaffer.properties.app-description would return:
```
"This is a description about the this application"
```

/properties/gaffer.properties.some-hidden-property would throw some error saying something like "gaffer.properties.some-hidden-property" is not a recognised property.



The system-description property could then be used in issue #1419.

title: API report for GCHQ Graph
body:
Hi,

Here is the report on API changes and backward binary compatibility for the GCHQ Graph library: https://abi-laboratory.pro/java/tracker/timeline/gchq-graph/

The report is generated by the https://github.com/lvc/japi-compliance-checker tool for jars at http://central.maven.org/maven2/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/graph/ according to https://wiki.eclipse.org/Evolving_Java-based_APIs_2.

Hope it will be helpful for users and maintainers of the library to be aware of past and future API changes.

The tool checks all public API methods and classes. Please let me know if it should not check some parts of the API.

Please also let me know if you'd like to see more components of the library in the tracker.

Thank you.

![gchq-graph-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1517837/31326114-0c1bcabe-accd-11e7-93b0-9ecbd4f40fe3.png)
![gchq-graph-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1517837/31326113-0c1bc5c8-accd-11e7-8a65-d57e68f1671b.png)

title: Update store properties so setting the properties class is not required
body:
For example, currently you need both of these properties to use the Accumulo Store

```properties
gaffer.store.class=uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.accumulostore.AccumuloStore
gaffer.store.properties.class=uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.accumulostore.AccumuloProperties
```

But the accumulo store should know that it needs to use the AccumuloProperties class.

title: Change All Spark Operations to accept Spark Session
body:
Some spark based operations accept sparksessions, while some acceptJavaSparkContext's, this should be standardised so all operations accept sparksessions, 

A better method of supplying the spark sessions to the operations is needed, currently a spark session is provided as a mandatory option on each operation, which has the side effect that spark operations can't be run over the rest service.

I propose we change this so that you create a gaffer "spark context" (inheriting from the gaffer context object)  in your store if you enable spark operations, which will then contain a spark session.which can be retrieved in the handler

title: Way to relate initial seed to output at the end of an operation chain
body: It would be really useful if there was a way to relate the results of a multihop operation chain to the initial seeds that were passed into the chain. If the operation chain has more than one operation and the end result elements/objects do not have an identifier that is easily relatable to any of the seeds that were passed in, then it is difficult to know which seeds resulted in which answers

title: GetDataFrameOfElementsHandler doesn't pass through options
body:
The `GetDataFrameOfElementsHandler` in the spark-accumulo module doesn't pass the options on the operation on to the underlying `GetRDDOfAllElements` operation. This means that the Hadoop configuration cannot be passed into this operation.

If you're running the code with the `hadoop` command or within a Spark job configured with a Hadoop configuration then it will work, but you can't override any parts of the configuration.

title: Spark operation examples don't show how to specify Hadoop conf
body: The examples for operations such as `GetJavaRDDOfAllElements` don't show how the Hadoop configuration can be passed in as an option. Passing this option in isn't essential if you're running your code either via the `hadoop` command or within a Spark job that has been configured with Hadoop, but it means you can't override properties in the configuration.

FederatedStore deadlock after failed addGraph.
body:
Bug replication:

Error is thrown while adding a graph with Schama collision gh-1304.
But the schema belonging to the failed "add graph" has been added to the graphLibrary, which is unexpected by user.

Every subsequent add graph with correct and legal schema will now fail.
Suspected because the in memory schema held in the FedStore instance has been updated with the previously wrong schema.

Can be recovered using a removeGraph with the failing graphId. then the subsequent correct addGraph works.

title: Gh 910 javadoc
Allow FederatedStore to be used with Schemas containing conflicting groups
body:
Currently the FederatedStore requires all schemas to be 'mergeable', they must not have conflicting groups.

This issue would be to allow conflicting groups, as long as they are not used together in a single query.

Graph | A | B | C
-|-|-|-
Schema Group | 1 | 1 | 2
property | propX | propY | propZ

Graph A & B would clash, GetAllElements operations should notify the user that this will occur.
Graph A & C is fine.
User1 might not have visibility of Graph B so GetAllElements should work fine with visable Graph A & C.

title: Add support in the Parquet Store to natively handle the AgeOff predicate
body: Without the native support of the AgeOff Predicate in the Parquet Store, all queries will need to be re-validated client side and it will make queries significantly slower.

title: Gh 1294 remove unused addgraph
Create GetWalks operation
body:
This operation would allow users to traverse a Gaffer graph and return the walk from each seed to the destination. The path returned should be a list of the Edges traversed (including properties).

The GetWalks operation could simply have a list of GetElements operations. The operation could then be handled by executing a GetElements operation, adding the results to an in memory set, extracting the the vertex at the other end of the edge, then executing the next operation.

After each stage we should remove Edges from the in memory set that are no longer required to reduce the amount of memory used.

After all GetElements operations have been executed we would then need to build up the list of paths.

The return type could be Iterable<Walk>, where a walk contains the edges traversed. For example if you queried for A and B.

[
[A->C, C->D],
[A->C, C-E],
[B->D, D->F]
[B->A, A->C]
]

title: Gh 1289 update accumulo
body: Before merging this in we need to check the gaffer-tools 'slider' implementation will still work.

title: gh-910-federatedstore-javadoc
FederatedStore use CreateGraphDelegate for init
body: Explore and use if CreateGraphDelegate can be used for federated store init. This would remove some code duplication.

title: Cache graphs in FederatedStore
body:
A FederatedStore restart or re-initialisation would cause the federatedStore to loose all graphs added since the previous re-start/initialisation by users. This would require all graphs to be re-added all over again by users.

FederatedStore should be able to "save" all the graphs in scope and their auths.

This could also provide an Audit.

❓Thoughts required around using a cache to be storing internal details in the situation of crash, everything is automatically saved at all times.

title: Add Auths to FederatedAddGraphHandler
If validation fails, AddElements should return a reason why
body: When adding elements, if validation fails then a useful error message containing the reason why it failed should be return. Currently it is can be very difficult to work out which property is invalid.

body: Due to the CreateGraphDelegate and creating a graph from the graphLibrary. A lot of the AddGraphs public methods are not used in production code. This should be removed and the test moved over or checked against CreateGraphDelegate.

title: gh-1291 - Filter function added, FilterStream functionality added
body:
Filter function added, taking in an iterable of Elements and an ElementFilter, returning a filtered iterable of Elements (or the original iterable if the ElementFilter is null).

For utility purposes, a FilterStreamSupplier and StreamFitlerIterable were written to facilitate the new functionality. (with thanks to @t616178! )

title: Create Transform operation
body: Create a new Filter operation that takes an iterable of elements and an ElementTransform. The handler should just apply the transformations to the elements.

title: Create Filter operation
body: Create a new Filter operation that takes an iterable of elements and ElementFilters. The fields should be similar to the View, with edges, entities, globalElements, globalEdges, globalEntities.

title: Create Aggregate operation
body:
This new Aggregation operation should take an iterable of Elements and apply the aggregation in the View/Schema.

This will be useful for Stores that don't support Aggregation natively and will allow users to transform Elements and then apply aggregation in a chain, e.g:

GetElements
    - view
        -transform - trim whitespace from vertices
Aggregate

The handler for the operation just needs to call AggregateUtil.queryAggregate(elements, view, schema);

title: Using the MiniAccumuloStore in Travis CI causes the jobs to be killed
body:
We have had to disable 2 spark-accumulo-library tests from running in Travis CI due to the jobs always being killed - probably due to using too much memory. They rely on the MiniAccumuloStore, so it is probably that, which is causing the problems.

We need to get those 2 tests running in Travis CI again. They can be enabled again by removing this block from the parent pom:

```xml
<exclude.tests>**/sparkaccumulo/integration/**/*IT.java</exclude.tests>
```

In the REST API version 2, when using an OperationChain you need to set the class field. 

For backwards compatibility, version 1 should not require this. The IOperationService class for version 1 of the rest api should use OperationChainDAO instead of OperationChain.

Update GetElementsWithinSet and GetElementsBetweenSets to set the matchedVertex field. 

GetElementsBetweenSets should set the matchedVertex to be the vertex matched in set A.

title: GetAdjacentIds with a view containing entity filters is invalid
body:
We should validate the GetAdjacentIds operations and if the view contains any entities with filters then we should throw an exception.

When an GetAdjacentIds operation is handled it does not load any entities so no entity filters can be applied.

title: FederatedStore-code-improvements
Provide ability to remove a whole group from an instance of a schema
body:
In order to change which groups certain users are able to see, we would like to remove whole groups from schema's used in specific REST service deployments.  I.e. the schema overall could contain:

Group A, Group B, Group C

But in one specific REST deployment we only want the schema to contain:

Group A, Group C - there-by hiding Group B

title: Javadoc typo and alignment.
Question: Operation specific config not being read
body:
hi again :)

I'm trying to add trace logging when I run my operation without affecting everyone else's, but it seems to just use whatever the defaults are. I've traced through and it looks like when it's deserialising the custom config stored at Hadoop_Configuration_Key in the operation, it reads -17 as the length and then ignores any of the config. Am I doing something wrong? Is there some other way of adding custom config?

The code I'm using is below: 

```
val customhadoopconffile = new FileInputStream("/path/to/myconf.xml")
val conf = new Configuration()
conf.addResource(customhadoopconffile)
val baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream()
val dataoutput = new DataOutputStream(baos)
conf.write(dataoutput)
val myhadoopconf = new String(baos.toByteArray(), "UTF-8")

...

val operation = new GetRDDOfElements.Builder().input(new EntitySeed("0.0.0.0")).option("Hadoop_Configuration_Key", myhadoopconf).sparkContext(sc).build()
```

myconf.xml is:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?><configuration>
  <property>
    <name>AccumuloInputFormat.GeneralOpts.LogLevel</name>
    <value>5000</value>
  </property>
</configuration>
```

Thanks,
Amanda

title: gh-1269 typo
FederatedStoreWalkthrough typo
gh-1267 - updated example button in swagger
body:
To test this:
- start the example rest api
- go to operations/execute
- in the dropdown select an operation
- click add example
- select another operation

title: Updating develop with release branch

HBase backend using deprecated class HTable
body:
The [HBase backend is using the `HTable` class](https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/blob/94f97b4aedf6ed3342ece4f042a2cbec4a90038b/store-implementation/hbase-store/src/main/java/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/hbasestore/HBaseStore.java#L159-L168). It has been deprecated in HBase 1.0 and the `Table` class should be used instead.

As we can see in the [Javadoc for `HTable` in HBase 1.3.0](https://static.javadoc.io/org.apache.hbase/hbase-client/1.3.0/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/client/HTable.html):

> `HTable` is no longer a client API. Use [`Table`](https://static.javadoc.io/org.apache.hbase/hbase-client/1.3.0/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/client/Table.html) instead. It is marked InterfaceAudience.Private as of hbase-1.0.0 indicating that this is an HBase-internal class as defined in Hadoop Interface Classification. There are no guarantees for backwards source / binary compatibility and methods or the class can change or go away without deprecation.

title: gh-1135 - updated doc for ordered serialisers
body:
##### Serialisers
Gaffer will automatically choose serialisers for you for some core types.
Where possible you should let Gaffer choose for you, as it will choose the optimal
serialiser for the type and your usage.

For custom types you will need to write your own serialiser. When manually
choosing a serialiser for your schema you will need to take the following into
consideration.

For vertex serialisation and groupBy properties you must choose serialisers that
are consistent. A consistent serialiser will serialise the equal objects into
exactly the same values (bytes). For example the JavaSerialiser and
FreqMapSerialiser are not consistent.

When using an ordered store (a store that implements the ORDERED StoreTrait),
this includes Accumulo and HBase, you need to check whether the serialisers are
ordered.

 - for vertex serialisation you must use a serialiser that is ordered
 - for groupBy properties we recommend using a serialiser that is ordered, however it is not essential. In fact it will not cause any problems at present. In the future we plan to add features that would only be available to you if your groupBy properties are serialised using ordered serialisers.
 - all other properties can be serialised with ordered/unordered serialisers.

title: Add GraphLibrary to FederatedStore
Gh 1137 override shallow clone
Improve Ingest for Parquet store from RDD
body:
Currently with the ingest process for very large volumes of data, the aggregation job can take a long time.

Therefore I propose the ingest process from RDD's could be changed to:
- take a sample of data to generate suitable split points or take the previous data's index as the split points
- write out the unsorted data into folders for each range of vertex and src values
- aggregate each folder adding in the existing corresponding data (This will prevent the whole lot of data needing to me in memory at once and should make the solution much more scalable)
- load in the whole groups data, sort by vertex/src and write out to desired number of files
- copy over the src folder's data and sort by dest to generate the dest sorted data
- generate the indices

```java
final OperationChain<Iterable<? extends EntitySeed>> opChain = new OperationChain.Builder()
    .first(new GetElements.Builder()
        .input(new EntitySeed("A0"))
        .build())
    .then(new ToVertices())
    .then(new ToEntitySeeds())
    .then(new ExportToSet<>())

    .then(new ToVertices())
    .then(new ToEntitySeeds())

```

title: gh-1176 - added hllp serialisers to accumulo and hbase rest
Add protection to our BinaryOperators to prevent objects growing too large
body:
Objects like FreqMap should only be used with a small number of keys, otherwise we could end up hitting limits in accumulo/hbase for the size of the rows.

In our BinaryOperators (like FreqMapAggregator), before merging the objects we should check whether the result will be too big. The aggregator should be configured with the key size limit. It should also have a flag to control what to do in the case that the objects cannot be safely merged - either throw an exception or log a warning and truncate the objects. If an exception is thrown then this will have severe consequences for Accumulo's tablet servers (similarly in HBase). 

This will require changes to the binary operators in Koryphe too.

title: Gh 1105 extra default parquet serialisers
Gh-1103 ParquetFilterUtil now uses the index for view filters where possible
Parquet store - maximise use of index for view filters
body:
When generating the path to filter mapping, we could make use of the indices to reduce the number of files to query by applying the following logic within the ParquetFilterUtils class.
If the selection column is not indexed then return set of all paths in graph/Group=X,
Otherwise:
IsEqualTo - returns the list of files which could contain the desired value
IsLessThan(OrEqual) - returns the list of files which could contain the desired value and all files before them
IsMoreThan(OrEqual) - returns the list of files which could contain the desired value and all files after them

If only one column in the selection then:
And - find the intersection of the two sets of paths
Or - merge the two sets of paths
Not - return set of all paths in graph/Group=X

If there are multiple columns in the selection then:
And - pick the set of paths with the fewest number of files
Or - return set of all paths in graph/Group=X
Not - return set of all paths in graph/Group=X

title: gh-1144 - changed LimitedSortedSet to LimitedSortedInMemoryIterable
Gh 1085 lock down graph export
Sort operation will skip elements when comparator returns 0
body:
The Sort operation uses a TreeSet to sort the results. The TreeSet implementation performs all element comparisons using the comparator, so two elements that are deemed equal by the comparator will be deduplicated.

For example if you use the Sort operation to sort the the following 2 entities based on the value of the count property:

```java
final Entity entity1 = new Entity.Builder()
        .group(TestGroups.ENTITY)
        .vertex("1")
        .property("count", 1)
        .build();
final Entity entity2 = new Entity.Builder()
        .group(TestGroups.ENTITY)
        .vertex("2")
        .property("count", 1)
        .build();
```
then you would just get back 1 of the entity as they are deemed to be equal and are deduplicated.

We recommend not using the Sort operation until it has been fixed. In the meantime there are Max and a Min Operations that you could use.

You can easily disable the Sort operation by creating a file (DisableSortOperation.json) containing the following:

```json
{
  "operations": [
    {
      "operation": "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.operation.impl.compare.Sort",
      "handler": null
    }
  ]
}
```

then added it to your store properties:
```properties
gaffer.store.operation.declarations=DisableSortOperation.json
```

Clarify warning message "serialiser is used for a 'group by' property in an ordered store and it does not preserve the order of bytes"
body:
The `SchemaOptimiser` warns if the serialiser used for a group by property does not preserve the ordering of the property (see line 112). This warning message is confusing:

- It doesn't tell the user how worried they should be - they have to guess at the implications - does it mean that they will get incorrect results (presumably not as if so it should be an error), does it mean that performance will be slower, does it mean that range scans won't work?
- Currently the fact that the serialiser doesn't preserve ordering doesn't cause any issues at all (although see #1134). In future, if we we optimise queries that specify filters on the first N of the group-by properties then the serialiser would need to preserve the ordering.

title: Serialisers of group-by properties for ordered stores should be consistent
body:
If the serialiser for a group-by property isn't consistent (i.e. the same object may potentially be serialised in two different ways) then ingest aggregation in the `AccumuloStore` will not work properly. This is because the group-by properties will not necessarily appear in the correct order (note this is a different, but related, issue to the need for the group-by properties to preserve ordering - here the property may not be comparable so ordering won't be preserved but it's still important for all of the same group-by properties to appear in consecutive rows). Currently the only indication a user will get of that is the warning message "serialiser is used for a 'group by' property in an ordered store and it does not preserve the order of bytes" (as the serialiser will presumably be marked as not preserving ordering).

An example of this would be if a user used a `FreqMap` as a group-by property. The serialiser iterates through the `HashMap` writing out the keys and values. The ordering of the keys is not guaranteed so the same map may serialise in 2 different ways.

Options - the first of these is probably best:
- Introduce a method on `Serialiser` to indicate whether the serialisation is consistent. Check that this is true for any property that is used in a group-by in `AccumuloStore` and other similar stores.
- Add Javadoc to `Serialiser` which says that it is assumed that `Serialiser` is consistent (this would require a non-breaking change to `FreqMapSerialiser`).

We should think about how this relates to the current warning message if a serialiser for a group-by property does not preserve ordering (see #1135) - are they independent concepts or should there be a hierarchy: doesn't preserve ordering and may not be consistent; consistent but may not preserve ordering or there might not be an ordering; consistent and preserve ordering?

To a user who specifies a group-by property that isn't serialised consistently then this would appear to be a bug as they might get results in which the ingest aggregation has not happened. Hence this issue is marked as a bug as we should reject such a schema for stores that can't deal with it.

title: Error in AccumuloStore wiki page
body:
There are 2 errors:

- The table that shows the key, value pair that is created for an `Entity` in the classic key package is wrong - there isn't a `01` at the end of the row-key and it should say "timestamp" under the timestamp column and "all other properties" should be moved under "value".
- The hyperlinks in the line "See the Key-packages part of the Implementation details section of this guide for more..." are broken.

title: Use SparkSession in Spark operations
body:
The operation `GetRDDOfElements` requires a `SparkContext`; the operation `GetJavaRDDOfElements` requires a `JavaSparkContext`; the operation `GetDataFrameOfElements` requires an `SQLContext`. It would be more consistent to require a `SparkSession` for all of these and obtain a `SparkContext` or `JavaSparkContext` from that as necessary.

This should be done before version 1 as it will cause users to have to change the code they use to get Spark RDDs/Dataframes.

title: gh-1098 - Added JSON Serialisation Abstract Test
body:
Created default implementation for JSON serialisation.
Due to type erasure, couldn't manage to keep the Deserialisation from a path, but a default to and from method is provided as a minimum.
Abstract method just needs to return a new instance of the class under test.

title: Java 9 migration
body:
There are a number of performance improvements that can be realised by enabling projects to be run in a Java 9 environment, even without making use of any additional language features:

https://www.sitepoint.com/inside-java-9-part-ii/

Java 9 is due to land in September, and some sources are advocating migrating codebases to take advantage of some of the new platform improvements.

Migration guide available here:

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/migrate/toc.htm#JSMIG-GUID-2C896CA8-927C-4381-A737-B1D81D964B7B

It'd obviously difficult to quantify any performance improvements without carrying out the migration, but this might be interesting in the future.

PS. This really needs a "p:very low" label!

Parquet store fails to addElements when using HDFS
body: The final task for the addElements operations is to move the data from the tempDir/sorted to the dataDir/timestamp, which works fine when working on the local file system. However if you are working on HDFS then the files will be moved to dataDir/timestamp/sorted.

title: Identify a way of turning off the Parquet logging
body:
The logging done by the Apache Parquet project produces a lot of logging which we would deem Debug logging which currently comes out as:
```
26-Jul-2017 15:20:42 INFO: org.apache.parquet.hadoop.ColumnChunkPageWriteStore: written 118B for [SOURCE] INT64: 100 values, 74B raw, 74B comp, 1 pages, encodings: [BIT_PACKED, PLAIN_DICTIONARY, RLE], dic { 25 entries, 200B raw, 25B comp}
26-Jul-2017 15:20:42 INFO: org.apache.parquet.hadoop.ColumnChunkPageWriteStore: written 118B for [DESTINATION] INT64: 100 values, 74B raw, 74B comp, 1 pages, encodings: [BIT_PACKED, PLAIN_DICTIONARY, RLE], dic { 25 entries, 200B raw, 25B comp}
26-Jul-2017 15:20:42 INFO: org.apache.parquet.hadoop.ColumnChunkPageWriteStore: written 48B for [DIRECTED] BOOLEAN: 100 values, 20B raw, 20B comp, 1 pages, encodings: [BIT_PACKED, PLAIN, RLE]
parquet.hadoop.ParquetRecordReader WARN  - Can not initialize counter due to context is not a instance of TaskInputOutputContext, but is org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.task.TaskAttemptContextImpl
```

title: Validate the names of Groups and properties
body:
If a group contains '=' then it will break the parquet store.
If a property contains '=', '.' or '_' then it will break the parquet store.
Currently the property names are checked in the SchemaUtils class for the Parquet store however both of these should be enforced for all the stores to allow for easy migration between stores.

title: Batch seeds for GetElementsHandler for the Parquet Store
body: Currently the `GetElementsHandler` reads all the seeds into memory which will OOM if the iterable is large. It should be changed to query for the seeds in batches.

title: Support views in GetDataFrameOfElementsHandler in ParquetStore
body: Turn a view into Spark filters that can be applied to the DataFrame before it is returned to the user.

title: Implement GetAdjacentIDsHandler for Parquet Store
Provide a Spring Cloud compatible health endpoint
body: Gaffer currently provides a status endpoint, which gives information about whether a given graph is live or not.  It would also be helpful to have an endpoint which provides Spring Cloud compatible responses (https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/production-ready-endpoints.html)

title: Add extra default Parquet serialisers
body:
Add extra default Parquet serialisers for common classes used as identifiers or properties, such as:
- TypeSubTypeValue
- Arrays
- Sets
- other sketches

title: Allow the indexing of selected properties in the ParquetStore
body:
It should be possible to index Gaffer properties as well as the identifiers.
The naive way would be to do the same as we do for the indexing the Destination. It may be possible to improve the indexing to require less storage when indexing columns by having a master copy of the data sorted by a record ID and for each index property or identifier store that value along with the recordID. This will slow down the query's slightly but it would drastically reduce storage if indexing many columns.

title: Improve how the Parquet Index is generated
body:
Currently the index is generated by taking the min and max statistics for each column related to the Gaffer identifiers. This causes a problem when the identifier is split into more than 1 column as the second column's last value may not be the max value. Really this needs to get the first and last row in each file and record the value for each column related to the Gaffer identifier.
This would then allow for the accurate targeting of filters to files when the identifier is split over more than one column.

title: Refactor the ParquetFilterUtils class in the ParquetStore
body:
This class has become long and complex and needs refactoring.
While refactoring, it should be possible to target the view filters to specific files if the column is an indexed column.

title: Update the ImportRDDOfElementsHandler and the AddElementsHandler for the ParquetStore
body:
Change the ImportRDDOfElementsHandler to aggregate the data without needing to write it out unsorted. Then if the group is an entity then it can convert the elements to Rows and then do the sorting, or if it is an Edge group then write out the aggregated data which can then be loaded in twice to do the sorting by Source and Destination.
Change the AddElements to do a similar thing except it has to write out the unsorted data before it can do the aggregation and sorting in a similar way.

title: Implement Age-off for the ParquetStore
body:
Create an operation which loads in the current snapshot of data and filters it based on the AgeOff function. It is probably best to do this on a per group directory basis.  Then you would delete previous snapshots.
This will need some thinking around how to manage users reading the data at the time of the AgeOff operation running.

title: Implement the Visibility trait to the ParquetStore
body: This should just require the adding of a visibility column which can be validated against by the ParquetElementRetriever before returning an element

title: Create an abstract class 'JsonSerialiseableTest' to be used by all classes that should be json serialisable
body:
This abstract class should have an abstract method:

```java
@Test
public abstract void shouldJsonSerialiseAndDeserialise();
```

We have several existing abstract classes that contain this method - these should be updated to extend the JsonSerialiseableTest class.

It would be useful to have some sort of default implementation if possible.

body: Register all the core/type/types classes into the uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/spark/serialisation/kryo/Registrator class, which will speed up the serialisation of those classes when performing Spark operations.

title: Gh 1089 graph hooks
Make it easier to register custom json serialisers in the REST API
body:
If you want to use a custom json serialiser in the REST API, there is several classes to change. We need a simpler way a user can just register their serialisers with the RestJsonProvider without having to create/modify multiple classes. 

An example of the current required process can be found here: https://github.com/gchq/gaffer-experimental/tree/customJsonSerialiserInRestApi/example/example-rest/src/main/java/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/rest

- Create a new RestJsonProvider class: https://github.com/gchq/gaffer-experimental/blob/customJsonSerialiserInRestApi/example/example-rest/src/main/java/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/rest/serialisation/ExampleRestJsonProvider.java

- Register it in your ApplicationConfig: https://github.com/gchq/gaffer-experimental/blob/customJsonSerialiserInRestApi/example/example-rest/src/main/java/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/rest/application/ExampleApplicationConfig.java

- Register the ApplicationConfig class in your web.xml: https://github.com/gchq/gaffer-experimental/blob/customJsonSerialiserInRestApi/example/example-rest/src/main/webapp/WEB-INF/web.xml


We should add the HyperLogLogPlusJsonSerialiser and HyperLogLogPlusJsonDeserialiser classes by default in the accumulo-rest and hbase-rest modules.

title: If validation fails, AddElements should return a reason why
body:
When adding elements, if validation fails then a useful error message containing the reason why it failed should be return. Currently it is can be very difficult to work out which property is invalid.

Example: when calling AddElements with an incorrect property type valve (String instead of int). Will fail operation, and describe the element is not valid, but does not provide the details regarding why and what is invalid with the given element. finding the faulty property requires debugging through the code, instead of looking at debug logs.

Gh 792 Spark GraphX operations
body:
First pass at including some GraphX operations for Gaffer, including:

* Creation of Graph objects from RDDs and Iterables
* Execution of the built in PageRank implementation from the GraphX library.

There are still some outstanding issues (lack of integration testing, correct setup of the SparkContext for the operations) and the implementation is very basic/simple/naive at the moment.

title: Gh 1060 multi property aggregation
body:
A lot of the files that have changed are simply the schema json files.

dataSchema.json -> elements.json
dataTypes.json + storeTypes.json -> types.json

In some cases we used a storeSchema.json file that contained a vertex serialiser. This has been renamed to serialisation.json.

Advanced aggregation and validation has been separated out into aggregation.json and validation.json. 

Renaming these schema files is not a breaking change and does not require users to do the same. I just think that for new users it will be clearer and easier to understand if we split the schema into just the elements and the types.

I have written quite a few unit tests to check the logic for the multi property schema aggregation, but it is a bit tricky so please review that bit carefully.

The change has added an extra section to the Schema but this is optional so hopefully it won't complicate things for novice users of Gaffer. There was a bit of complexity around the change due to not be able to aggregation multiple properties together if they are stored in different places. For example - we will not allow groupBy and non-groupBy properties to be aggregated using the same BinaryOperator. 

See #1060 for a discussion around this feature and for the update Schema wiki page content.

Before we merge this in we should check that we are all happy with the extra "aggregator" section in the schema and that it doesn't complicate things for users.

title: Gh 287 refactor export to other graph handler

ExportToOtherGraphHandler#createGraph

potentially the method fields could be removed and the inner three methods be simply passed export & store. this would be in keeping with the clean practice of small method parameter volume.

title: Lock down ExportToOtherGraph based on user auths
body:
Currently any user can export any Graph in any way.  This needs to be locked down to allow only certain users to export to specific places.

We need to disable the ability to add a custom schema and custom store properties. Then require either an existing graphId or parentSchemaId and parentStorePropertiesId. Then we would need to validate the user has the required authorisations to use graphId, parentSchemaId and storePropertiesId.

title: Add an option to the Limit operation to throw an exception if the limit is reached
body:
Currently the limit operation just truncates an input iterable to the desired maximum length. This means users cannot tell if they have had results removed. 

In some cases it would be useful to throw an exception instead. This could be implemented by adding a truncate boolean field to the Limit, LimitedCloseableIteratable and LimitedCloseableIterator classes. This should be set to true by default. If truncate is set to true then the iterable should be truncated as it currently is. If set to false, then an exception should be thrown, telling the user there were more items in the iterable than the provided limit.

body: We need to implement AddOperationsToChain with NamedOperations to ensure the OperationChain within a NamedOperation is also updated.

title: Add migration steps to the Accumulo Store README
body:
Currently we don't provide any documentation on how update a Schema in Accumulo. We need to add a section into the Accumulo Store README containing the following information (copied from issue #1058):


You can do the following:
- add new groups
- add new non-groupBy properties (including visibility and timestamp), but they must go after the other properties
- rename properties
- change aggregators
- change validators
- change descriptions

You cannot do the following:
- rename groups
- remove any properties (groupBy, non-groupBy, visibility or timestamp)
- add new groupBy properties
- reorder any of the properties. In the Accumulo store we don't use any property names, we just rely on the order the properties are defined in the schema.
- change the way properties or vertices are serialised - i.e don't change the serialisers.
- change which properties are groupBy

Please note, that the validation functions in the schema can be a bit dangerous. If an element is found to be invalid then the element will be permanently deleted from the table. So, be very careful when making changes to your schema that you don't accidentally make all your existing elements invalid as you will quickly realise all your data has been deleted. For example, if you add a new property 'prop1' and set the validateFunctions to be a single Exists predicate. Then when that Exists predicate is applied to all of your existing elements, those old elements will fail validation and be removed.


Once you have your updated schema, all you need to do is update the Accumulo table's iterators with the new schema's.
And We have a utility for this 
https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/blob/master/store-implementation/accumulo-store/src/main/java/uk/gov/gchq/gaffer/accumulostore/utils/AddUpdateTableIterator.java

You need to provide a comma separated list of schema file paths,  a store Properties file path and the argument: update.

You can do this programatically through the class by calling main method with the above arguments.
Admittedly It's not the most publicly facing API at the moment, we've had some other thoughts around storing schema's in some kind of central location - which could also then make it much simpler to update them on the stores. But we've not really looked at this too much.



If you have existing data, then before doing any form of upgrade or change to your table I would strongly recommend using the accumulo shell to clone the table so you have a backup so you can easily restore to that version if things go wrong. Even if you have an error like the one above where all your data is deleted in your table you will still be able to quickly revert back to your backup. Cloning a table in Accumulo is very simple and fast (it doesn't actually copy the data). If you have a table called 'table1', you can do something like the following in the Accumulo shell
```bash
> offline -t table1
> clone table table1 table1-backup
> offline -t table1-backup

# Do your upgrades
#   - deploy new gaffer jars to accumulo
#   - run the AddUpdateTableIterator class to update table1

> online -t table1

# Check table1 is still healthy:
#   - run a query and check the iterators are successfully aggregating and filtering elements correctly.

> droptable -t table1-backup
```

title: Allow multiple properties to be aggregated using a single aggregate function
body:
We need to update the SchemaElementDefinition class to allow a ElementAggregator to be provided. Then getFullAggregator, getIngestAggregator and getQueryAggregator methods will need to be updated to use combine the Type aggregators and the schema element definition aggregator.

We need to restrict which properties can be aggregated at the same time. For example, you should not be allow to aggregate a groupBy property and a non-groupBy property in the same Binary Operator. When ingest aggregation is applied, only the non-groupBy properties are aggregated so we need Binary Operators that only apply to non-groupBy properties. The different types of properties are: groupBy, non-groupBy, visibility, timestamp. 


As schemas can be split up into different files we probably should have another think about the structure of these files and in which file the new ElementAggregator functions go. The aggregation logic is Store specific so it shouldn't be mixed up with the other data schema parts. 

We could change the schema files (dataSchema, dataTypes, storeTypes) to be something like:

- schema
- types
- serialisation   (store specific)
- validation    (overrides type validation and allows you to validate multiple properties at once)
- aggregation   (overrides type aggregation and allows you to aggregate multiple properties at once)

title: gh-659 - updated tests to use the edge builder

title: Aggregation on multiple properties and schema changes
body:
Got a couple issues that I've been spending some time with workarounds and want to make sure I'm not missing anything.  Am working with accumulo store, in case that is relevant.  If there is documentation somewhere that I'm missing that addresses these feel free to just point me to it, as I could easily have missed it.  Thanks!

1. I find myself sometimes wanting to aggregate a property based on other properties (not just the one I'm aggregating on), specifically based on the timestamp (ie. often something simple like grabbing the latest).  From a looking at the code I'm not sure a reason it couldn't be supported (at least in the accumulo case) but it didn't seem like it is.  Writing a schema i've found myself just wrapping the timestamp in the property so it's not that big of a deal, but adds some duplication and can prevent me from using something simple like a primitive type.

2.   For my use-case I need to be flexible in allowing the creation of new types of elements.  Is there any documentation on migrating to a schema with an added element group?  Will simply providing a new schema at runtime with the new element group be an issue, or does it require an export/import to a new accumulo data store?  I can add the new type into a groupBy field instead of making it a element group, but seems a bit wrong to do so.

These aren't always issues, but on a couple element groups they are.

title: Gh 1050 consistent add named operation json serialisation
Multiple Data Types With AddElementsFromHDFS/SampleDataForSplitPoints
body:
The AddElementsFromHdfs and SampleDataForSplitPoints operations allow users to specify mutliple input paths but only a single mapperGenerator.

There will be situations where we want to add multiple data types (from different hdfs directories) to a Gaffer graph. We should be able to specify pairs of input path(s) to mappergenerators.

This will also be more efficient because we will be correctly sampling from the full data range for the table split points in Accumulo. And we can consolidate multiple bulk-loads into a single job.

title: Handlers in spark-accumulo-library don't set column families
body:
Handlers for operations that return Spark RDDs or Dataframes on the `AccumuloStore` don't set the column families to read (e.g. in `GetJavaRDDOfElementsHandler`). So they are not taking advantage of the locality groups, and are reading unnecessary data.

This can be solved by using `InputConfigurator.fetchColumns(...)`.

This doesn't affect the results that are returned, so it hasn't been marked as a bug, but the intention was that all operations that can take advantage of the locality groups do so, so arguably it is a bug.

title: Increase default value of accumulo.maxBufferSizeForBatchWriterInBytes
body: The default value of `accumulo.maxBufferSizeForBatchWriterInBytes` is set to 1,000,000 in `AccumuloProperties`. This is less than 1MB. Much better ingest performance can be obtained if this is set to 100MB. Suggest increasing the default to 100,000,000.

gh-538 - Make REST API more RESTful and update to version 2.
body:
Some questions regarding the change to the REST API in version 2:

* I have added a custom media type to indicate to the REST client which version of the API their request has been executed against. I can remove this if we think it's not useful, or we could implement this differently (for example, by adding a custom header to the response)
* I've added a additional endpoint (/latest) which redirects to the latest version of the API - is this useful?
* At the moment, only one version of the API can be served up through Swagger - this needs to be configured by the application. Are there use cases where we would want to allow access to all versions of the API via Swagger?
* Some methods have been changed to return Jersey ```Response``` objects - this allows for greater control over the object which is returned to the calling service (e.g. headers, status codes etc). Is it worth standardising this across the services so that all methods are treated the same?

title: Add a graphId to uniquely identify an instance of a Gaffer graph
body:
A large number of files have changed, but the change in the majority of files is just to simply added a graphId whenever a Graph is instantiated or a Store is initialised.

I have also deprecated the 'table' property in HBase and Accumulo, so these stores will now use the graphId as a table name.

This is needed for issue gh-954. The rest of the changes for that issue will come later. The final part of that issue is to add the Graph Library. The Graph Library needs this graphId to uniquely identify a schema and store properties.

title: The Raw Serialisers do not preserve object ordering
body:
The Raw Serialisers (RawLongSerialiser, RawDateSerialiser, etc.) do not always preserve object ordering.

For example if you serialise the following longs you, they should be serialised into bytes that maintains the same ordering.

1. 1496709602656   ->  [96, 29, -40, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
2. 1496710980959   ->  [95, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
3. 1496710980960   ->  [96, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
4. 1496710980961   ->  [97, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]

So the values of the serialised bytes ends up reordering the values into:

2. 1496710980959   ->  [95, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
1. 1496709602656   ->  [96, 29, -40, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
3. 1496710980960   ->  [96, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]
4. 1496710980961   ->  [97, 37, -19, 122, 92, 1, 0, 0]


The ordering of the serialisers is important when using an ordered database/store, like Accumulo or HBase. If using either of these Gaffer Stores, you should use an serialiser that preserves object ordering for your vertices. If your vertices are serialised on an ordered fashion then you are able to do [range scans](https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/wiki/Accumulo-specific-operation-examples#getelementsinranges-example).

It is advised that Properties included in the groupBy should also be serialised with an ordered serialiser to help maintain true ordering of the Accumulo/HBase row keys. However, this is not essential, but you will not be able to carry out range scans over other columns in the row key (column qualifier/visibility).

To fix this bug, we should deprecate all of the Raw Serialisers and write new serialisers based on:
https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/f81a8ec7410e789d11941351d5899b8894c6a322/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/client/lexicoder/ULongLexicoder.java.

We will need to update the Serialisation Factories, removing the deprecated serialisers and adding the new ones. This will break the serialisation of all the serialised data that has been serialised with the Raw Serialisers and have not explicitly defined them in their schema. This would occur due to new serialisation factory selecting the new serialiser, which will not be compatible with the existing serialised bytes. We must inform users that if they have an existing table in accumulo or hbase that they need to manually define the Raw Serialisers they are using in their schema.

title: gh-981 - Fixed the accumulo and hbase table utils
Existing Gaffer Accumulo tables pre 0.7.4 cannot be migrated to 0.7.4
body:
The AddUpdateTableIterator utility is used to migrate an accumulo table from one version to the next. However, the utility validates the table prior to upgrading it and if the validation fails then the table will not be upgraded.

The Accumulo aggregator iterator config was changed in 0.7.4 and this means the utility will always fail to run.

As a work around you will need to open the accumulo shell and manually update the Aggregator iterator config before running the AddUpdateTableIterator utility:

```bash
config -t <table-name> -s table.iterator.majc.Aggregator.opt.columns=<csv of your gaffer element groups>
config -t <table-name> -s table.iterator.minc.Aggregator.opt.columns=<csv of your gaffer element groups>
config -t <table-name> -s table.iterator.scan.Aggregator.opt.columns=<csv of your gaffer element groups>

config -t <table-name> -d table.iterator.majc.Aggregator.opt.all
config -t <table-name> -d table.iterator.minc.Aggregator.opt.all
config -t <table-name> -d table.iterator.scan.Aggregator.opt.all
```

The Count operation handler should not use parallel streams

In CountHandler change:
```java
return Streams.toParallelStream(operation.getInput()).count();
```
to
```java
return Streams.toStream(operation.getInput()).count();
```

title: The job tracker will not be updated if an Error is thrown

However, the try catch block only catches Exception objects not Error objects so the job tracker will never be update in the event an Error occurs such as OutOfMemoryError.

See Store execute and executeJob methods.

title: GH-952 - updates to groupIds in documention
Create a federated Gaffer Store
Create a Graph Library to store and retrieve Schemas and StoreProperties
body:
Currently every time you construct a Graph instance you need to provide the original Schema and store properties. If the Graph instance is constructed with a different Schema then it will conflict with the original Schema and cause problems.

The Schema and Store Properties should be persisted by the Graph using a GraphLibrary so it doesn't have to be provided every time a user constructs a new Graph instance.

To implement this change we will need to introduce a few new IDs. A Schema ID, a Store Properties ID and a Graph ID. The Graph ID should be used to uniquely define a graph - it will be associated with a Schema ID and a Store Properties ID. 

We should write a GraphLibrary interface that has methods for persisting and retrieving schemas and store properties.

Then we can update the Graph.Builder class to allow Graphs to be built using just a Graph ID (and GraphLibrary), in which the Schema and Store Properties can be retrieved from the GraphLibrary.

Alternatively a user could create a new Graph with a new Graph ID, new Schema, but refer to existing Store Properties using a Store Properties ID.

In the case of accumulo and hbase, we should remove the 'accumulo.table' and 'hbase.table' properties and use the graphId instead. 

Note the Schema persisted should be the full (non-compact) schema including all the description fields.

title: Gh 874 accumulo and hbase serialisers

This page: https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/wiki/User-Guide has two POM dependencies for getting started:

<dependency>
    <groupId>uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.core</groupId>
    <artifactId>graph</artifactId>
    <version>[gaffer.version]</version>
</dependency>
<dependency>
    <groupId>uk.gov.gchq.gaffer</groupId>
    <artifactId>accumulo-store</artifactId>
    <version>[gaffer.version]</version>
</dependency>

When I put it in my POM (with version 0.7.3) and started building I got this error:
"The POM for uk.gov.gchq.gaffer.core:graph:jar:0.7.3 is missing, no dependency information available"

Looking around at the project, I dropped the ".core" in the first dependency group, changing it to: "uk.gov.gchq.gaffer", rebuilt and it completed build and has been working (so far).  

So, I think this is just a small documentation update...



Thanks,
Jeff

title: Validate operation chain input/output types
body:
If operation chains are built using the OperationChain builder then users will get compile time errors if the order of operations in their chain is invalid. The output of an operation must be compatible with the import of the next operation.

If users create operation chains via rest or python then the operation chain input/output types are not validated. User's will only notice a problem at runtime if the chain fails to execute and a class cast exception is thrown.

Prior to executing the operation chain the store already does some validation of the chain. This validation should be split into a separate class and updated to include the input/output type validation.

In addition it would be really helpful to have a rest api method 'getNextOperations' that takes an operation class and returns all the operations that would be valid to come next.

title: Gh 752 edge seed direction enum
Updating develop with release branch
Updating master with release 0.7.3
Create an Apache Parquet backed store
body:
It would be useful to have a store that scales well and is suitable for carrying out full table scans.
Apache Parquet seems to be a good candidate as Spark has been optimised for high performance reads of Parquet data. By sorting the data before writing, Parquet can be optimised for random access as well as full scans.

The initial version should include:
- Support for ingest aggregation
- Support for seeded queries with pre-aggregation filters that naturally fit to Parquet filters
- Store the data in an optimised way to make best use of the Parquet file format
- Expose the data as a Spark Dataframe

The Initial version will not be suitable for:
- Streaming data into
- Query time transformations
- Query time aggregation
- Fine grain security

Typical use cases could include:
- For applying a Page Rank algorithm against yesterday's data
- As part of a larger system where you stream data into a different store to act as your days cache, while still query able and then overnight load that days data into a Parquet store where it is available for full table scan queries as well as random access queries.

title: gh-921 - Remove the toCloseableIterable Collector

title: gh-919 - count groups handler now closes the input
CountGroupsHandler does not close the input iterable
body:
The CountGroupsHandler should call close on the operation once it has finished iterating around the input elements.

Normally the iterable of elements returned from Accumulo/HBase will automatically close when the end of the iterable is reached. The CountGroups handler will stop iterating if it hits a limit so the input should be manually closed.

title: Improve GetAdjacentIds Accumulo and HBase handlers
body:
To get an adjacent vertex, the Accumulo and HBase operation handlers fetch the entire Edge object and then simply extracts the destination vertex. It would be more efficient to just fetch the destination vertex.

The handler also relies on a magic operation option 'return_matched_id_as_edge_source' which returns edges with the source and destination flipped so the source is the vertex that was matched against a seed. This option can cause confusion as directed edges may be returned the wrong way around. We should investigate if there is a clearer way of doing this. Perhaps returned a different type of edge, e.g a BackwardsEdge or changing the directed field to be an Enum - FORWARDS, BACKWARDS, FORWARDS_DIR, BACKWARDS_DIR.

title: Change Serialisation api to allow objects to be serialised into different types
Reduce the number of times byte arrays are copied

The Serialisation class serialises objects into byte arrays. In accumulo and hbase these byte arrays are then copied into another byte[] and then store in an accumulo/hbase row/column/value. 

Perhaps we could add a serialise method that takes a byte[] or some byte writer and can write directly to that byte[]/writer:
```java
void serialise(Object, byte[] result)
```
or
```java
void serialise(Object, ByteWriter writer)
```

title: Create general purpose aggregation operations

These would be executed client side and so would best suited to stores which are hosted on a single node (e.g. in-memory stores like the MapStore). For distributed store types this would be inefficient, so an ideal implementation of these default aggregation operations would delegate to the underlying store if necessary.

As this will increase over time (as new features are added), any efforts to reduce the running time of the tests (for example, by using the build matrix to run the unit tests and integration tests separately or by running tests for each store in parallel) would be of benefit.

title: SampleDataForSplitPoints and SplitTable don't work together
body:
In the `AccumuloStore`, the `SampleDataForSplitPointsHandler` uses `SampleDataAndCreateSplitsFileTool` to sample some split points and write them to file. They are written to file base64 encoded.

The `SplitTableHandler` uses `SplitTableTool` to read the split points in from file and apply them to the table. The base64 encoding is not undone when they are read from file.

This explains why only one tablet server receives data even if split points have been applied.

This should be fixed and a unit test created.

title: Unnecessary line in AddElementsFromHdfsIT
body:
The test `AddElementsFromHdfsIT` in the Accumulo store contains the following at line 212:

    store.updateConfiguration(createLocalConf(), new View(), new User());

This line is:
- Unnecessary - the test passes without it. 
- Pointless - it updates the configuration created by `createLocalConf()` but that configuration is not used again.
- Misleading - it looks like the `updateConfiguration` method is used to cause operations on the graph like `AddElementsFromHdfs` to use a particular configuration - that's not true. In this test a local MapReduce configuration is somehow automatically created and used.
