title: Or and And predicates only accept a single property
body:
Since updating to use the Koryphe functions library in version 0.7.0 the Or and And Predicates now only work with a single property.

 For example you can select a property (e.g count) and pass that same property value to multiple predicates:

```java
new View.Builder()
        .edge("RedEdge", new ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
                .preAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
                                .select("count")
                                .execute(new Or<>(new IsLessThan(2L), new IsMoreThan(10L)))
                                .build())
                .build())
        .build()
```

Prior to 0.7.0 you could select multiple properties then within the Or function you could do select which properties to pass to which functions, it was complicated to write but it used to work like this:
```java
new View.Builder()
        .edge("RedEdge", new ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
                .preAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
                                .select("count", "average")
                                .execute( new Or(new ConsumerFunctionContext.Builder<Integer, FilterFunction>()
                                                .select(0) // select first property
                                                .execute(new IsLessThan(2))
                                                .build(),
                                        new ConsumerFunctionContext.Builder<Integer, FilterFunction>()
                                                .select(1) // select second property
                                                .execute(new IsMoreThan(5.1))
                                                .build())))
                                .build())
                .build())
        .build()
```

title: Updating develop with release branch
Updating master with release 0.7.0
Gh 785 doc
Allow named operations to be run with custom parameters
body:
Currently when you run a NamedOperation you can set a custom view. This is applied to all operations in the named operation chain that don't have a predefined view. This doesn't work very well and does provide enough flexibility for users to configure parts of the named operation such as filtering values.

We should remove the ability provide a view in the NamedOperation class - i.e remove "implements OperationView".

Instead we need to add allow users to do something like:

```java
new NamedOperation.Builder()
    .name("1-hop")
    .input(new EntitySeed("vertex1"))
    .parameter("maxCount", 10)
    .parameter("minStartDate", "01/01/2017")
    .build();
```

The "1-hop" named operation could have an operation defined similar to:
```
new GetElements.Builder()
                .view("redEdge", new ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
                        .preAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
                                .select("count")
                                .execute(new IsLessThan(${maxCount}))
                                .select("startDate")
                                .execute(new IsMoreThan(${minStartDate}))
                                .build())
                        .build()
                .build();
```

So named operations need to have custom parameters that will be resolved when it is executed. The parameters should also be able to have default values and a description.

title: gh-862 - Refactoring logging to not string concat
SampleDataForSplitPointsJobFactory should get compression options from the operation
body:
`SampleDataForSplitPointsJobFactory` is hard-coded to use gzip and block compression in the `SequenceFile`s that will be output by the job. There are currently no unit tests for this job.

When writing a unit test for some code in `gaffer-tools` that need to run this sample data job, the error message "SequenceFile doesn't work with GzipCodec without native-hadoop code!" is returned.

The operation should allow the type of compression to be specified. Unit tests can then turn compression off to avoid this error.

gh-xxx - Fixed a number of small code quality issues which do not deserve their own issue reference.
body:
* Added missing @Override annotations
* Added some missing equals/hashCode implementations
* Fixed some encapsulation issues
* Changed catch blocks with Throwables to Exceptions (should not be trying to catch and handle Errors)
* Adopted usage of Collection.isEmpty() rather than explicit tests against Collection.size()
* Corrected ordering of some equality tests involving string literals
* Removed redundant "throws" statements for runtime exceptions.
* Removed redundant (non-clarifying) parentheses.
* Added some missing final qualifier.
* Reordered some fields declarations 
* Flattened some deeply nested if() statements

title: Refactor argument construction in logging statements
body:
Passing concatenated strings into a logging method can incur a needless performance hit because the concatenation will be performed every time the method is called, whether or not the log level is low enough to show the message.

For example:

```java
LOGGER.error("No class type found for type definition " + typeName
                            + " used by identifier " + idType
                            + ". Please ensure it is defined in the schema.");
```

Should become

```java
LOGGER.error("No class type found for type definition {} used by identifier {}." +
                       "Please ensure it is defined in the schema.", typeName, idType);
```

title: Change GraphConfigurationService to use URIs rather than URLs
body: The equals and hashCode methods of java.net.URL both make calls out to the Internet and are blocking operations. URI on the other hand makes no such calls and should be used since the specific URL functionality is not required.

title: Add DEBUG system property to include stack trace in REST error messages
body:
Currently, the errors provided by the REST API include a representation of the full stack trace in the body of the error message. Often this message is not very useful to the end user - the default state should be that the stack trace is not included, but there should be an option to include it if required.

This could be implemented using a JsonFilter - either by creating a new filter which implements the Jackson PropertyFilter interface, or by making use of the field exclusion filter which is provided as part of the Gaffer JSONSerialiser class.

title: Gh 781 null pointer missing operation declarations file
Add method to rest api to execute a single operation
body:
If a user wants to run a non-core operation such as NamedOperation via the rest api, they currently have to wrap it in an operation chain and executing via the execute(OperationChain) method.

It would be nice to have an method execute(Operation) that users could use.

This will mean the Operation class will need to be annotated with:

```java
@JsonTypeInfo(use = JsonTypeInfo.Id.CLASS, include = JsonTypeInfo.As.PROPERTY, property = "class")
```

to tell Jackson how to deserialise the operation json.

After this issue is done we will need to add the same method to the python shell in gaffer-tools.

title: gh-775 Integration Test Coverage: NoAggregationIT
Create operations for standard functions like max
body:
There is an operation called `Count` that simply counts the number of items in a provided iterable. This was introduced because the `MapStore` can optimise an operation chain that retrieves all elements (with the standard `View`) and then counts the number of them, into a single operation that is implemented very efficiently (see issue #802).

We should provide other operations like max, min and sum that can be used on properties on elements returned from queries. For example a query may return an iterable of elements, and the user may want to return only the element with the largest value of a "count" long property.

Users of the Java API may find it easiest to perform these operations by converting the iterable of results into a Java Stream, and then call standard Java functions. However, these cannot be used over the REST API. The advantage of wrapping standard functions in operations is that they can then be put into operation chains and used via REST.

title: Check that table was created by Gaffer when initialising AccumuloStore
body:
It is surprisingly common for users to think they need to manually create a table in Accumulo before creating an `AccumuloStore`. If they do this then the table will not have the correct Bloom filters and iterators set, and this will cause poor performance and errors.

We should investigate setting a configuration property on a table when Gaffer creates it. Whenever a new store is created against that table, then the property could be checked, and if it is not present then the creation of the store should fail (if there are scenarios where experienced users may need to manually create a table and add iterators, then there could be an option on the store properties to ignore this warning, and carry on, but the default should be to fail).

title: Upgrade from to version 0.9.1 of the DataSketches library

title: Remove the Accumulo Pair class
body: There are multiple separate implementations of Pair-like data structures in the Gaffer project. These should be removed and replaced with a single implementation which is used consistently throughout the project.

title: Create TimestampSet property
body:
It is common to want to store a set of timestamps, to some accuracy, on an `Entity` or `Edge`. For example, store all the times the edge was observed, to minute-level accuracy.

A class should be created that is constructed with a particular accuracy level, e.g. minute or hour, and allows timestamps to be added. Internally, these are truncated to the requested accuracy (e.g. the seconds and milliseconds are removed if minute-level accuracy has been requested), converted to an int (e.g. number of minutes since the epoch), and stored in a `RoaringBitMap`. The class can be queried to produce a list of all the timestamps that have been added.

An aggregators and a serialiser for the class should also be written. These can basically wrap the existing aggregator and serialiser for `RoaringBitMap`.

title: Provide example of filtering in views based on the source or destination
body:
Provide an example of how filters in views can take into account the values of the source or destination, e.g. the following view specifies that the destination should be "A" (of course if there is only a single seed "B" then it would be more efficient to just query for the edge A-B - it would be more interesting to filter by destination matching a regular expression - the example could show this use-case as well):

    View view = new View.Builder().edge("EDGE",
                    new ViewElementDefinition.Builder().preAggregationFilter(
                        new ElementFilter.Builder()
                                .select(IdentifierType.DESTINATION.name())
                                .execute(
                                        new IsEqual("A"))
                                .build())
                        .build())
                    .build();

An example should also be provided of the affects of these filters for undirected edges. For example, if undirected edge B-A is inserted into a graph, and B is queried for, with a filter saying that the destination should be A or match A* then no results will be returned, because B is the destination (as they are automatically reordered so that A is the source). When executing such queries on undirected edges, the user should specify that either the source or the destination is A (it will be interesting to see how easy this is to specify in the current select, execute model of filters).

title: Investigate improving Kryo serialisation for classes from DataSketches
body: It should be possible to register the classes from the DataSketches library that we have serialisers for in the Kryo Registrator. Their existing serialisers should just be wrapped in Kryo serialisers. This should improve the performance of Spark jobs which use them. This may not be simple though because some of the classes, e.g. `DoublesUnion`, are abstract which seems to cause Kryo problems in finding the correct serialiser. The classes that implement the abstract classes (e.g. `HeapDoublesUnion`) are not visible outside the DataSketches library so serialisers for them cannot be provided.

title: Gh 803 improve kryo serialisation in spark library2
Gh 659 consistent edge creation
body:
I have made the Edge class immutable (removed default constructors and setters). I've also done the same to the Entity class to have some consistency between the two Element implementations.

The classes are not *fully* immutable currently. In order to swap the source and destination in the Edge class I have kept the fields non-final. I have also left the "putIdentifier" methods on both classes. This is currently used only when creating ElementTuple objects, but it does allow a way of modifying the fields on an Element. If this is undesirable, then I'd suggest opening two new issues:

* Move vertex swapping in the Edge class to Builder method. This will have the side effect of forcing the source and destination to be specified when invoking the build() method. Currently it's possible to create an empty Edge (i.e new Edge.Builder().build()), which has null for both source and destination.
* Make ElementTuple immutable.

Apologies for the number of changes - this was always going to be a problem when changing the Edge and Entity classes.

title: Collaboration with DataSketches.github.io
body:
@p013570 

I can see that your Gaffer team is using a number of sketches from our library.  Excellent.  We also get a number of queries about use of sketches in graph databases.  We can certainly point to Gaffer, but I think a closer collaboration would be beneficial.  We have a number of new sketches in development, for example the VarOpt sketch for superior accuracy for weighted "reservoir" sampling.  I would like to get some feedback on your interest in new sketch types as well as questions or comments on usability or documentation of our library.  If you are interested, you can start a discussion on https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/sketches-user, or add an issue to https://github.com/DataSketches/sketches-core/issues.  Thanks.

title: Add getGroupByFunction method to schema and view
body:
This would return a Function similar to:

```java
element -> element.getProperty("property1");
```

this could then be used in a groupingBy collector, e.g:

```
Collectors.groupingBy(groupByFunction);
```

where the function groups by all properties that are in the groupBy array in the schema or view.

All groupBy property values would need to be classes that have an implementation of hashCode and equals.

Create an operation "Sort" that takes a comparator and sorts an iterable of Elements.

A simple comparator should be provided that takes a property name and compares the property values (assuming they are comparable).

As part of this issue we should also create a SortExample that extends OperationExample.

Remove BiFunction from Koryphe
body:
Koryphe currently supports both BinaryOperator and BiFunction, but BiFunction is only used to implement aggregation where the output type is different to the input type. These examples would be clearer if implemented by applying a function to either the input or output of a BinaryOperator.

Any other uses of BiFunction should be implemented as a Function that accepts a Tuple input type.

title: gh-817 - fixed a few issues with the ui
UI fails to wrap number strings vertices in quotes
body:
When using the UI, queries that return vertices that are number strings (i.e. "1") are not quoted so it is added to the UI as an integer (i.e. 1). This means if you try to use this integer vertex in a second query an error will be thrown.

String results in the UI should be wrapped in quotes.

An attempt to fix this was done in issue gh-724 but the fix doesn't properly check result vertices.

Gh 811 map store parallel aggregation
Map Store applies aggregation in parallel
body:
When elements are added it does StreamSupport.stream(elements.spliterator(), true) so it adds them in parallel. This means the aggregation is done in parallel and we could end up with the same count property being incorrectly updated at the same time in different threads.

For the time being this should be changed to not do it in parallel. In the future we could write an implementation of spliterator that splits on groups

Mark `Schema`, `Graph`, `Store` and `StoreProperties` as Java Serializable
body: We shoul mark `Schema`, `Graph`, `Store` and `StoreProperties` as Java Serializable. This will enable them to be used in closures in Spark operations. We need to make sure any transient variables are marked as such.

title: Improve Kryo serialisation in spark-library
body:
Currently only `Entity`, `Edge` and `Properties` are registered in the `Registrator` class in the spark library. We should register other classes such as `FreqMap`, `HyperLogLogPlus` and the other sketches. We should provide implementations of the serialisers for classes that may be difficult/expensive to serialise (e.g. `HyperLogLogPlus`).

We should also investigate registering other classes such as `Schema`, `Graph`, `Store` and `StoreProperties`. In order to serialise `Schema`, we need to use the de.javakaffee:kryo-serialisers project, and call `UnmodifiableCollectionsSerializer.registerSerializers` in the `registerClasses` method.

title: Create chain optimiser for the MapStore
body: The `MapStore` has a handler for the `CountAllElementsDefaultView` operation that allows the calculation of the number of elements in the store without needing to iterate through every element. An operation chain optimiser should be written that converts a `GetAllElements` operation (with the view set to everything, and the options set to include everything) followed by a `Count` operation to a single  `CountAllElementsDefaultView` operation. This may best be done after version 0.7 when the number of options on the operations have been reduced.

title: Implement the visibility trait for the MapStore
body: The `MapStore` does not currently implement the `VISIBILITY` trait. Support for this should be added.

title: Implement query aggregation for the Map store
body: The `MapStore` does not currently support the `QUERY_AGGREGATION` trait. Support for this should be added.

Remove the array list store
body: The current ArrayListStore is very basic and doesn't really demonstrate good practices for a Gaffer store. It has been left in the repository as an example of a second Store implementation, but with the addition of the Java Map store the Array List store can now be deleted.

body: It would be useful to be able to create GraphX graphs from the results of a "GetElements" query in order to use the Spark GraphX API to perform analysis on Gaffer graphs.

This may effect the way the elements are grouped in the Java Map store gh-776.

title: Gh 93 function interfaces

Consistent usage of final keyword
body: There is currently inconsistent usage of the final keyword throughout the project, particularly within try-catch blocks. This should be updated so that the usage is applied consistently.

title: Improve the wiki
body:
It would be better for pages like the Accumulo store guide to live as a README.md file alongside the accumulo store implementation. Then when releases are done we can copy the README.md file onto the wiki. This way it would stay more up to date and be versioned with Gaffer releases.

We should add a message similar to:

"This page been copied from [README](https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/blob/master/store-implementation/accumulo-store/README.md). To make changes please update the README.md."


There are several different types of users of Gaffer so we should split up the Getting Started page to target the different users:
- Quick Start
- Configuring Gaffer - how to write custom functions, operations, schema, etc.
- Querying Gaffer - how to execute operations

The getting started guide would be easier to follow if each step built on the previous. To do this, I suggest using the Road Traffic example in Gaffer Tools as a basis and building up to the fully working Road Traffic example.

title: gh-783 added support for global filters in named op views
NamedOperation views don't allow global filters to be used
body:
Currently any global filters on a named operation are not expanded so the filters are not added to each element group - i.e. the global filters are not applied.

The Graph class will normally handle this for all operation views. However, the named operation contains a nested operation chain that is not passed through the setup in the Graph class. This means the named operation handler has to call view.expandGlobalDefinitions() on the views in the named operation chain itself.

title: NPE if sparkContext not provided in GetRDDOfElementsHandler
body:
If a `SparkContext` is not provided in a `GetRDDOfElements` operation then when it is executed a `NullPointerException` is thrown in the handler. A more useful exception should be thrown.

The other operations involving Spark should also be checked for this problem.

title: NullPointerException if the operation declarations file is missing
body: If a graph is created when the store properties file contains say "gaffer.store.operation.declarations=/path/to/file" property, but the file does not exist, then a `NullPointerException` is thrown. A more useful exception should be thrown.

title: Gh 734 useful operations
body: Should be merged in after gh-93.

title: Move the functions (koryphe) library out of Gaffer to a dedicated repository
body: The functions library should be moved out of Gaffer and into it's own repository so that it can easily be shared between projects.

title: Gh 467 seed hierarchy
body: Sorry another big pull request. I have basically replaced all uses of ElementSeed with ElementId.

title: Gh 776 map store
Create in-memory store backed by a Java Map
body:
It would be useful to have an in-memory store. The first version of this will use a standard Java HashMap. It will not scale to large volumes, but it will be very high performance for queries. It should be optimised to support aggregation efficiently.

This has the following use-cases:
- A simple in-memory cache of `Element`s that have been retrieved from a large store.
- The creation of examples of how operations work, how views work, etc, without the need to use the `AccumuloStore`.
- The aggregation of data within a streaming process, i.e. ingest data into an in-memory map aggregating properties if the same element is seen multiple times followed by periodic export of the whole graph into a larger (e.g. Accumulo-based) store.

Future versions of this could use libraries that allow off-heap storage to allow scalability to larger volumes, but the initial version will use a Java HashMap.

title: Integration tests fail to spot that the same edge must be output twice if it was added twice and no aggregation is specified
body:
This issue arose when writing a new store. If aggregation is not being used (either the store doesn't support it or it is just not being used) then if the same edge is added twice, it should be returned twice from a query. If a store erroneously only returns the edge once, the integration tests don't spot that.

The integration tests should be extended so that they test if no aggregation is being used then the same edge should be returned twice if it was added twice.

Marked as a bug as this means an incorrect store implementation can pass the integration tests.

title: Gh 419 op options
Remove GetEdges and GetEntities operations
body:
To avoid duplicating all element operations 3 times we should remove Entity and Edge specific operations. Users can restrict the types of elements that are returned by providing an Operation View containing the different edge and entity groups they would like to be returned.

This will be done as part of gh-419.

title: Updating develop with release branch
Updating master with release 0.6.3
Gh 719 wiki
Updating master with release 0.6.3
gh-762 - Applied fixes to support of Accumulo 1.8
Create and integrate common cache service
body:
Currently there are a number of cache-dependent components all around Gaffer, such as the Named Operations and Job Trackers. There is a growing need for a common cache service that would remove repeated caching logic from these components and provide an interface for new cache-reliant features. 

Users may want to use a different cache implementation depending on their requirements (i.e. JCS, Hazelcast, Ehcache etc). Therefore the gaffer cache service hides the implementation behind an interface and loads the exact service at runtime using a system variable. This provides a clean interface for all components to use, whilst providing options in terms of specific implementation.

To start with the cache service will provide 3 implementations: JCS, Hazelcast and a basic HashMap. This can be expanded if required.

title: Support for multiple versions of Accumulo does not work well in IDE
body:
Currently the Accumulo version is specified by a Maven profile - this means that the IDE does not have the correct JARs for both supported versions of Accumulo on the classpath at compile time.

The Accumulo store should be refactored to fix this.

title: gh-756 - Added exception in the event that the table name is not specified
gh-754 - Removed unused constants
gh-757 - fixed schema validation
Allow per-group specification of aggregation
body: Currently aggregation has to happen for all groups or none. It would be useful to be able to do aggregation of properties (e.g. HyperLogLogPlus sketches) for Entities, but store all individual occurrences of Edges.

title: Invalid schema not detected
body:
With the schema below, if the same edge is inserted twice, its properties silently disappear (if only one instance of the edge is inserted the properties are present). This schema should not be allowed because aggregation should (currently) be specified for all properties or none, but no error is given.

    Schema schema = new Schema.Builder()
               .type("intnoagg", new TypeDefinition.Builder()
                       .clazz(Integer.class)
                       .build())
               .type("int", new TypeDefinition.Builder()
                       .clazz(Integer.class)
                       .aggregateFunction(new Sum())
                       .build())
               .type("string", new TypeDefinition.Builder()
                       .clazz(String.class)
                       .aggregateFunction(new StringConcat())
                       .build())
               .type("boolean", Boolean.class)
               .edge("EDGE", new SchemaEdgeDefinition.Builder()
                       .source("string")
                       .destination("string")
                       .directed("boolean")
                       .property("p", "intnoagg")
                       .build())
               .entity("ENTITY", new SchemaEntityDefinition.Builder()
                       .vertex("string")
                       .property("p2", "int")
                       .build())
               .build();

title: NPE if table is not set in AccumuloStore
body:
This code throws a NullPointerException because the table name has not been set (if a line is added to set the table name on properties it's fine) - it should throw a more useful exception.

     Schema schema = new Schema.Builder()
                .type("int", Integer.class)
                .type("string", String.class)
                .type("boolean", Boolean.class)
                .edge("EDGE", new SchemaEdgeDefinition.Builder()
                        .source("string")
                        .destination("string")
                        .directed("boolean")
                    .build())
                .build();

     AccumuloProperties properties = new AccumuloProperties();
     properties.setStoreClass(SingleUseMockAccumuloStore.class.getName());

     Graph graph = new Graph.Builder()
                .addSchema(schema)
                .storeProperties(properties)
                .build();

title: Correct dependency information in README
body: The README says "To use Gaffer on Accumulo the only required dependency is the accumulo-store dependency" but that doesn't have a dependency on the graph module. We should update the README to say that both these dependencies should be added.

title: Unused fields in AccumuloStoreConstants
body: `AccumuloStoreConstants` has several unused fields: TRANSFORM_PRIORITY, GAFFER_UTILS_TABLE, SCHEMA_KEY, KEY_PACKAGE_KEY. These should be deleted.

title: gh-719 - Updated wiki to include reference to JARs hosted in Maven central
Change directed field in EdgeSeed to directed, undirected or either
body:
In `EdgeSeed` you can specify whether the `Edge` you are looking for is directed or undirected, but you can't say you are looking for any edges between A and B irrespective of whether they're directed or not. The directed field should be changed so that it's either DIRECTED, UNDIRECTED or EITHER.

One of the key design criteria in version 1 of Gaffer was to be able to find all edges between A and B in a single range. The `ClassicKeyPackage` in the Accumulo store stores data in a way that allows a single range to be constructed, but the user is forced to specify multiple `EdgeSeed`s to get all edges between A and B. As part of this change the `ClassicKeyPackage` should be able to construct one range when the EITHER option is selected.

title: Error with new GetEdges.Builder<EdgeSeed>()
body:
When i write this code in Eclipse:
```
final GetEdges<EdgeSeed> operation = new GetEdges.Builder<EdgeSeed>()
        .addSeed(new EdgeSeed(1, 2, true))
        .addSeed(new EdgeSeed(2, 3, true))
        .build();
```
taken from the first **GetEdges example** of the [Operation examples wiki](https://github.com/gchq/Gaffer/wiki/Operation-examples#getedges-example), i get this error:
> Incorrect number of arguments for type GetEdges.Builder; it cannot be parameterized with arguments
> \<EdgeSeed\>

Maybe that the right code is the following?
```
final GetRelatedEdges<EdgeSeed> operation = new GetRelatedEdges.Builder<EdgeSeed>()
        .addSeed(new EdgeSeed(1, 2, true))
        .addSeed(new EdgeSeed(2, 3, true))
        .build();
```

title: Create an exporter to cache result objects
body:
This follows on from gh-720.

When an operation chain is run asynchronously any output results are just lost. So this issue is to implement an exporter that can be used in an operation chain to export any results (elements, seeds, any json serialisable objects) to cache. These results could then be looked up using the async job id. The cache would need to provide visibility filtering, age off and be capable of holding a large number of results. The type of cache should be configurable.

This is similar to gh-284 but 284 only considers exporting Gaffer Elements. This issue requires any type of result object to be cached.

title: Create Job Tracker and allow operation chains to be executed asynchronously
body:
### High level design

Create a separate method in the Graph class called "executeJob". This method would generate a 'jobId' (a random id based on the user id, timestamp and a random value) and this value would immediately be returned to the user. Create a new thread and delegate the operation chain to the execute method.

Asynchronous jobs will need to be tracked - so the jobId should be stored along with a job status in a 'Job Tracker' this could be backed various different caches.

An operation should be created to get the details of a job for a given job id.

Update to Java 1.8
Consistent src and dest in undirected edges
body:
An undirected edge A-B is identical to the undirected edge B-A, and the `equals()` method on `Edge` will return true in this case. However when `toString()` is called the string representation of the edge will be different. The JSON version of the edge will also be different. In older versions of Gaffer, undirected edges were always created in a consistent manner, with the source being lexicographically before the destination. As the source and destination are now just objects, there may be no natural ordering, but `toString()` can be used instead.

When the edge is created the logic would be:

    if source and destination are both instances of comparable:
         if destination < source
              swap destination and source
    else
          if destination.toString() < source.toString()
              swap destination and source

This should make it easier for non-Java consumers of the data to dedupe data.

Serialisation class Javadoc issues
body:
There are some issues with the Javadoc in the `Serialisation` class:

- The second line of the Javadoc at the top of the class is irrelevant - "As a minimum, any Serialisation mechanism must be able to serialise and deserialise any given Property" - there is no "Property" here - just a T. The first line is also confusing. It should be rewritten to say:
"A class that implements this interface is responsible for serialising an object of class T to a byte array, and for deserialising it back again. It must also be able to deal with serialising null values."
- The comment on the `deserialise` method should be rewritten to say "Deserialise an array of bytes to the original object."
- The comment on the `isByteOrderPreserved` method is confusing - it's not about whether the byte order is preserved - it's whether the serialised form preserves the ordering of the objects. The method should really be renamed to `preservesObjectOrder`. The Javadoc should also note what should be returned if this method makes no sense, e.g. if T is not `Comparable`. The Javadoc should say: "This method indicates whether the serialisation process preserves the ordering of the T, i.e. if x and y are objects of class T, and x is less than y, then this method should return true if the serialised form of x is guaranteed to be less than the serialised form of y (using the standard ordering of byte arrays). If T is not `Comparable` then this test makes no sense and false should be returned."

body:
Instead of the interface being:
```
void postExecute(final Object result, final OperationChain<?> opChain, final User user);
```

it could return the new result object
```
Object postExecute(final Object result, final OperationChain<?> opChain, final User user);
```

Currently it is assumed that most people won't need to run the examples as the output from them is included in the documentation on the wiki. However, the documentation should detail how to run the examples.

You can just get your IDE to run them directly for you. 

Or alternatively, first compile the example jar with all dependencies using the maven profile 'exampleJar':

```
mvn clean install -Pquick -PexampleJar
```

Then run an example using:

```
 java -cp example/example-graph/target/example-jar-with-dependencies.jar gaffer.example.gettingstarted.analytic.LoadAndQuery1
```

title: Operation chain limiter can fail if operation scores are loaded in an unexpected order

The operation chain limiter appears to require operation scores to be listed in ascending order, however it is possible for these to be loaded in a random order.

When loaded from disk, it must be ensured that the resulting Map is always ordered.

The current REST API does not look like a typical RESTful API (based around resource collections and the application of HTTP methods against those collections). Could the REST API be refactored slightly to align more closely with REST best practice? E.g. 
POST http://:/api/graph/get/elements/related
{
  "seeds" : [ "elementSeed1", "elementSeed2" ]
}
Could become: 
GET http://:/api/graph/elements/,/related

It would be neater to have an AddElements operation that takes a Source object, describing where the elements are coming from and how to add them to Gaffer.

Similar we have a few GetElements - e.g GetElements, GetJavaRDDOfAllElements, GetRDDOfElements, GetDataFrameOfElements.
It would be neater to have a GetElements operation that takes a Destination object, describing the format of the result.

This is a similar pattern to the Export operation with an Exporter. The Export operation could be deleted and these Exporters could be changed to work with GetElements and a Destination.

title: Gh 518 function-equals-hashCode-toString
Gh 422 spark dataframe configurable property conversion
Introduce concept of tag for groups
body:
The group of an element defines the properties that will be present on it. There are often natural groupings of groups, i.e. groups that are related in some way, e.g. red edges and red entities where the red entities contain properties that summarise the red edges. If groups could be tagged in the schema, and a tag used to create a view, then it would give an easy way to generate graphs containing groups that belong together.

An example would be having groups called red_edge_group, blue_edge_group, red_entity_group, big_edge_group, etc. Tags could be applied to the groups, e.g. red, colour, size. A view could be created from the red tag that would return just the red_edge_group and red_entity_group. A view from the colour tag would return red_edge_group, blue_edge_group, red_entity_group.

This is related to #519 but different as that is referring to filtering based on properties. This proposal does not involve adding a tag property to every element. It simply tags groups in the schema, so that domain knowledge of which groups belong together can be encoded in the schema and later used to easily produce views that contain elements that make sense.

This makes it easier to have rich graphs with lots of different types of data, but easily generate subgraphs with groups that together form a coherent view on the data. The ability to create your own view that produces exactly what you want would still exist.

title: Derive schema after view is applied
body: Executing a get operation with a view can cause data to be returned that is very different to the `Schema` of the graph: some groups can be filtered out, new properties can be derived, etc. Tools that receive data and want to know the structure have to derive the "schema" for the resulting elements themselves. There should be a standard method that returns the "schema" when a given `View` is applied.

title: gh-503 - added aggregation getting started example
Add an example of adding vertex cardinalities to the Getting Started guide
body:
This basically involves adding a 'Cardinality' Entity onto every vertex. The 'Cardinality' entity needs to have a HyperLogLogPlus property. Then in your element generator, whenever an edge (A to B) is created, it should also create cardinality entities at A and B.

These cardinality entities will then be aggregated automatically and will provide an estimate of the connectivity of each vertex in the graph.

To create the cardinality entities for an edge, you can do something like:
```java
final HyperLogLogPlus hllpSource = new HyperLogLogPlus(5, 5);
hllpSource.offer(edge.getDestination());
final Entity sourceCardinality = new Entity.Builder()
        .vertex(edge.getSource())
        .group("Cardinality")
        .property("edgeGroup", edge.getGroup())
        .property("hllp", hllpSource)
        .build();

final HyperLogLogPlus hllpDest = new HyperLogLogPlus(5, 5);
hllpSource.offer(edge.getSource());
final Entity destCardinality = new Entity.Builder()
        .vertex(edge.getDestination())
        .group("Cardinality")
        .property("edgeGroup", edge.getGroup())
        .property("hllp", hllpDest)
        .build();
```

title: Add validation to Schema for the use of the groupBy field with no aggregators
body: If no aggregators are provided in a schema, it is invalid for any properties to be added to the groupBy field. This should be checked in the schema validation.

title: The Accumulo store should work without aggregators
body:
A schema with no aggregators is valid. Currently the accumulo store cannot handle this case and will run into issues when trying to aggregate properties as it won't be able to find any aggregators in the schema.

If the accumulo store receives an schema with no aggregators it should configure the accumulo table using the versioning iterator (i.e don't delete it as we normally do) and don't add the aggregator iterator.

The operation handlers in Accumulo should also be updated to not use any query time aggregators.

title: Add validation to ViewElementDefinition Builder
body:
An exception should be thrown if an attempt is made to use the builder incorrectly. 

For example this is invalid:
```java
ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
      .postAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
              .select("property1")
              .execute(new IsMoreThan(5))
              .build())
      .postAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
              .select("property4")
              .execute(new IsMoreThan(8))
              .build())
  .build())
```

It should be used like this:
```java
ViewElementDefinition.Builder()
      .postAggregationFilter(new ElementFilter.Builder()
              .select("property1")
              .execute(new IsMoreThan(5))
              .select("property4")
              .execute(new IsMoreThan(8))
              .build())
  .build())
```

title: Move some flags from GetOperation to GetIterable operation
body:
There are several flags on GetOperation that only apply to iterables or elements. These should be moved to either a new operation GetIterable or GetElements.

``` java
GetIterable extends GetOperation<SEED_TYPE, Closeableiterable<RESULT_TYPE>>
```

``` java
GetElements extends GetIterable<? extends ElementSeed, ? extends Element>
```

GetIterable should have the following (moved from GetOperation):
resultLimit
deduplicate

GetElements should have the following (moved from GetOperation):
includeEdges
includeIncomingOutGoing
includeEntities
populateProperties
seedMatching
validateFlags

Allow the JSONSerialiser to be constructed with a custom object mapper
body:
Implementations may need to add custom serialisers/deserialisers and other configuration to the object mapper and currently this is not possible.

There should be a constructor that takes an instance of an ObjectMapper. Also, it may be able to get hold of the ObjectMapper instance via a getMapper method on the JsonSerialiser.

title: Enable REST API to chunk results
body:
This is to enable large volumes of data to be sent in chunks, so that the receiving end doesn’t have to deal with a single large JSON object. 

Would we need a new chunked REST end-point or could it be an option on the existing one? 

Changes:
1. Set the response header `Transfer-Encoding: chunked` and omit the `Content-Length` header. Server platforms often take care of this for you - Node and Jetty both support it out of the box. For more info see the MDN docs for Transfer-Encoding. 
2. Form the response in such a way that the browser can deal with it one line at a time. For example, CSV and newline-delimited JSON objects work well. A single JSON object or Array doesn't work because the browser needs to read the whole response into memory to parse it.

title: Improve the serialisers to improve handling of null values and empty byte arrays
body: Currently the Serialisation classes do not support custom handling for null values in a consistent way. This is an issue if there is a requirement for handling of non-standard edge cases (e.g. empty Strings as valid property values, as in the case of the visibility property).

title: Allow operations to be seeded with Elements as well as ElementSeeds
body:
ElementSeeds are just Elements with no group or properties. We could simplify operation chains and tidy up the GetAdjacentEntitySeeds operation if we could remove ElementSeeds.

Rather than removing we need to just change ElementSeed to be a parent of Element - or something similar.

title: Provide visibility serialiser that's compatible with Accumulo's built-in visibility filtering
body:
We should provide a serialiser for string visibilities that works as you'd expect with Accumulo's built-in visibility filtering approach, e.g. if the visibility is "vis1&vis2" and the user has Accumulo authorisations "vis1" and "vis2", then they should be able to see it. This serialiser should automatically be used if the provided visibility property is a string. It should deal with the valid visibility of the empty string.

Note that it's possible that this already works fine with our standard string serialiser, but there don't seem to be any unit tests that check the combination of visibilities is dealt with correctly.

title: Shaded jar names are inconsistent
body:
e.g.
- accumulo-store-iterators-${GAFFER_VERSION}.jar
- simple-serialisation-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-serialisers.jar
- simple-function-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-functions.jar

but the installed artefacts in your maven repository are called:
- accumulo-store-${GAFFER_VERSION}-iterators.jar
- simple-function-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-shaded.jar
- simple-serialisation-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-shaded.jar 

These are also referenced incorrectly in the accumulo store guide on the wiki.

The results should be the following:
- accumulo-store-${GAFFER_VERSION}-iterators.jar
- simple-serialisation-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-serialisers.jar
- simple-function-library-${GAFFER_VERSION}-functions.jar

This will involve adding something similar to the following in the poms:

``` xml
 <shadedArtifactAttached>true</shadedArtifactAttached>
<shadedClassifierName>[insert name]</shadedClassifierName>
```

title: Create Filter that avoids returning all edges twice when running a full table scan
body:
When running a MapReduce or Spark job over an entire Accumulo table, every edge will be returned twice as it is stored twice. This can be avoided by creating a Filter iterator that only returns true for one of the two keys that are created for an edge. This will require an additional method on `AccumuloElementConverter` which returns true for only one of the two keys associated to an edge.

Note that this is a different issue to the need to deduplicate when the same edge is returned twice from a query (e.g. because there is an edge A->B and both A and B were seeds for the query).

title: Add GetJavaRDDOfAllElementsOperation
body: For consistency with the operations that create Scala RDDs, there should be a `GetJavaRDDOfAllElementsOperation`.

title: Spark Dataframe operation should allow configurable conversion of properties to a Spark DataType
body:
In the handler for the `GetDataFrameOfElements` operation, it should be possible to configure how a Spark `DataType` is generated from a property (for example if the properties contain custom objects that Gaffer is not aware of then the user should be able to specify how a Spark `DataType` is generated from it).

The conversions that are automatically dealt with should be extended to include `FreqMap` and `HyperLogLogPlus`.

title: Indexing of properties in Accumulo store
body:
The `AccumuloStore` should offer the option to index properties. It seems difficult to index the properties that are constantly changing as they are being aggregated, but it should be possible to index the properties used in the `groupBy` values. If for example one of the group by properties was colour, then this would make it possible to ask questions such as "find all the red edges". This will require the creation of a separate table from the main graph table.

For some of the group by properties there may be a relatively large number of elements that match, so a sharded index may be best. Using a document-partitioned index will allow questions such as "find all the edges that are red and have property X".

Issues that will need consideration:
- How will age-off work in this index table (options include having one index table per time bucket, which would allow more efficient queries such as find all red elements on this day, or using the same criteria as used for age-off in the main graph table)?
- How will bulk import work (probably multiple MapReduce jobs will be needed, one for the main graph and one for each index)?

title: AbstractCoreKeyAccumuloElementConverter has unnecessary call to System.currentTimeMillis()
body:
There are two places in `AbstractCoreKeyAccumuloElementConverter` where there is a call to `System.currentTimeMillis()` which is ignored if a timestamp has been provided. As this is called for every `Element` that is inserted, that's a lot of potentially expensive overhead. The `buildTimestamp` method should call `System.currentTimeMillis()` only if it needs to because no timestamp has been provided.

Two other issues with this class could be fixed at the same time (separate issues can be raised if necessary): there is a reference to `new byte[0]` but elsewhere in the class `AccumuloStoreConstants.EMPTY_BYTES` is used instead; in `getKeyFromEntity` there is a comment that "Row key is formed from identifier and group" - this is not true - it should say "Row key is formed from vertex".

title: GetAllElements builder offers invalid method
body:
The `Builder` for `GetAllElements` offers an `addSeed` method but this is not valid for this operation. As the only reason for the existence of the builder is to make it easy to create a valid instance of the operation, it should not offer this method.

Also:
-  `GetAllElements` is a `GetElements<ElementSeed>` - shouldn't it be a `GetElements<Void>`?
- The `setIncludeIncomingOutGoing` method currently says that it is only possible to set this to outgoing edges only. This doesn't make sense - there is no concept of outgoing for `GetAllElements`. It would be better if this method threw an `IllegalArgumentException` (even if under the hood it uses that option to avoid returning the same edge twice).

title: Spark operation handlers for Accumulo store don't implement all options
body:
The following options on `GetRDDOfElements`, `GetRDDOfAllElements`, `GetJavaRDDOfElements` and `GetDataFrameOfElements` are either not implemented or cause exceptions or don't make sense: `deduplicate`, `limitResults`, `populateProperties`. For the latter operation, `addSeed` is offered but doesn't make sense.

Both the `deduplicate` and `limitResults` options on get operations assume that the result is a `CloseableIterable` - this is not true in the general case. Some operations will either not offer these options, or will implement them in their own way.

These issues have become more visible due to the recent changes to the builders which cause all methods to be exposed, but the issues were there before that.

Marking this as a bug because if the options are offered they should work.

However, it should be possible to extend this to deal with multiple groups: if two groups have the same property then the associated column can just have the property name; if a property P is only present in group G then the column name can be G_P to tell the user which group it came from. If there are multiple groups then a group column should be added.

title: Review Accumulo iterator stack
body:
We should review the current set of iterators in the Accumulo store, with the aim of:
- Ensuring that the current stack of iterators is properly documented somewhere.
- Reviewing whether any of the iterators needlessly deserialise key-values to elements and reserialise them back again (e.g. if a filter always returns true, there's no point in deserialising and reserialising).
- Look for opportunities to rationalise or merge iterators, e.g. could all current pre-aggregation iterators be done in one iterator to avoid multiple deserialisation and reserialisation?
- Review whether we should be lazily deserialising key-values to elements so that parts are only deserialised as necessary to run a filter or transform.

GetOperation shouldn't return an iterable
body:
The `GetOperation<SEED_TYPE, RETURN_TYPE>` interface extends `Operation<Iterable<SEED_TYPE>, Iterable<RETURN_TYPE>>`. A get operation might not return an iterable of results. In the case of getting a Spark RDD of results, it returns a single RDD, not an iterable. A get operation could also return its results as a single `Graph` object.

The `GetOperation` interface should be changed so that it extends `Operation<Iterable<SEED_TYPE>, RETURN_TYPE>`.

title: Serialisation of FreqMap
body: The serialisation of `FreqMap` currently works by converting the key-value pairs to strings and then joining them together with a delimiter. It should be possible to do this more efficiently, without the overhead of converting the integers to and from strings. If `FreqMapSerialiser` is changed, this would be a breaking change. Alternatively, a new separate serialiser could be written.

title: FreqMap for longs
body:
The `FreqMap` class currently maps strings to integers. It would be useful to be able to store longs in a frequency map. Serialising a long does not take any more space than serialising an int when the long is smaller than `Integer.MAX_VALUE`, so `FreqMap` could be changed to only deal with longs without any extra serialisation cost. Alternatively, a `LongFreqMap` class could be written. So the options are:
- Create a new `LongFreqMap` class.
- Change `FreqMap` so that it is a map from String to long.

As there is no serialisation overhead in using a long, I suggest option 2, but opinions are welcome.

This relates to #389.

title: Number of reducers for bulk import
body:
When bulk importing to Accumulo, the number of reducers is set based on the number of split points. This can cause problems in two situations:
- If there are a large number of split points, but a small amount of data is being ingested, then a large number of reducers are used and this can slow the job down. The method `connector.tableOperations.getSplits(<table name>,<max splits>)` provides optimal splits up to a maximum number.
- If there is a large amount of data to be imported, but the table is new and only has a small number of split points then there will be a small number of reducers and the job will take a long time to run.

Two options to the `AddElementsFromHdfs` operation should be added: the first allows a maximum number of reducers to be specified. The second causes more reducers than the number of splits to be used - there is a method on  `RangePartitioner` called `setNumSubBins` to help with this.

title: Specifying split file in Accumulo bulk import
body:
The split file for bulk imports to Accumulo is currently specified in two places: in the store properties (option `accumulo.splits.file.path`) and as an option on the `AddElementsFromHdfs` operation (`accumulostore.operation.hdfs.user_provided_splits_file`). The first case is used when the operation will create the splits file from the split points that are currently on the table; the latter is used when the user provides the split file (as should happen when the user samples the data to find sensible split points prior to the first import to the table).
- It is confusing that the splits file is specified in two different places depending on a subtle difference in use.
- The splits file does not belong in the store properties - it is a property of a particular bulk import operation, not the store. There might be multiple bulk import operations happening at the same time and in this case if the same store properties file was used then the files would clash. When this happens an IOException with the message "Resource hdfs://server/splits_file changed on src filesystem (expected ____ was ____)".

Suggest:
- The splits file should be removed from the store properties, and should always be specified by the option on the operation.
- There should be an option on the operation to say whether the splits are to be found from the table and written to the splits file, or to be taken from the user provided splits file.

title: Range scans and comparators
body:
When given a pair of `EntitySeeds`, the `GetElementsInRanges` operation returns all elements containing a vertex that is between the first and second `EntitySeed`. In the `AccumuloStore` this requires the vertex serialisation to preserve the ordering of the vertices. However the store does not know if this is the case. And the vertices might not even be comparable.

In more detail, the issues are:
- It is possible to apply the `GetElementsInRanges` operation to data with vertices which are not comparable. In this case the operation is meaningless and should not be allowed.
- If the vertices are comparable then the store does not know if the serialisation preserves the ordering. For example, if the vertex is an integer then a fixed length serialisation might preserve the ordering, but a variable length one would not. The store is therefore unable to decide if it can safely apply the operation.
- Some vertex types are naturally comparable in more than one way. For example, a type-value pair could be comparable in two different ways - considering type first then value, or value first then type. In the first case, typeA|value1 < typeB|avalue2; in the second the opposite is true, i.e. typeB|avalue2 < typeA|value1. Different serialisers can be chosen to preserve the first ordering or the second ordering. In this case the store needs to know which comparator the user wants to use for the range scan, and it needs to know whether the serialisation respects this.

This situation will lead to user error as they execute a range scan without understanding the subtleties.

Note that arguing that the ordering should purely be based on the serialised value of the vertices ignores stores that do not need to serialise data and which can do range scans based on the actual ordering of the objects.

A possible solution is:
- If the vertex is not Comparable then refuse to run the operation.
- If the vertex is Comparable then `GetElementsInRanges` assumes that this is in respect of the ordering specified by the compare method on the vertex (unless an option says otherwise - see next item). If this is running on a store that serialises the vertices, it asks the vertex serialiser whether it preserves the ordering. If it does it runs the operation; if not then it refuses to run the operation.
- If `GetElementsInRanges` is called with an option which says a specific Comparator is intended to be used then the vertex serialiser is asked whether it preserves the ordering specified by that Comparator. It it does, it runs the operation; if it doesn't it refuses.

Note that this is linked to #268 - the default serialiser for a vertex that is an int should probably be one that respects the natural ordering of ints; the default serialiser for an int that is just a property should be `CompactRawIntSerialiser`.

title: Hard-coded user in MockAccumuloStore
body: The `MockAccumuloStore` has a hard-coded user. Replacing this with the user from the `StoreProperties` causes no problems with the tests and would be more representative of the way the real `AccumuloStore` is used.

title: Create TypeValue vertex type
body:
It is common to identify a vertex using a pair of strings, type and value, e.g. customer A or film B. Serialisation of this pair of strings is not trivial, unless it is known for certain that a certain character, e.g. "|", will not appear in either the type or the value (in this case that character can be used as a delimiter). If this is not known, then the serialisation needs to delimit the two strings so that they can be unambiguously deserialised later. This needs to be done in a way that preserves the ordering so that range scans work. One way to do this is to convert each string to a byte array, remove the 0 byte from each of these using `ByteArrayEscapeUtils`, and then use the 0 byte as the delimiter. This should preserver the ordering.

Gaffer should provide a TypeValue type and a serialiser.

Additionally, a TypeSubtypeValue vertex could be provided.

title: Bulk import to Accumulo store
body:
To bulk import data to a new table in Accumulo, the following steps are necessary:
- Estimate split points from a sample of the data you want to ingest.
- Create table.
- Set the split points on the table.
- Convert the data to rfiles of Accumulo keys and values.
- Hand those files to Accumulo.

To help bulk import data to a new graph backed by an Accumulo store, the following operations are provided:
- `SampleDataForSplitPoints` - this creates a file of split points.
- `SplitTable` - this splits a table but does not create the table.
- `AddElementsFromHdfs` - this creates the table if it does not exist, but does not add split points. It hands the data over to Accumulo.

To use these operations to bulk import to a new graph, it is necessary to run `SampleDataForSplitPoints`, then run `SplitTable`, then run `AddElementsFromHdfs`. This is overly complex, and not documented properly.

It should be possible to run one operation, which bulk imports data to a new graph - this operation should run all the above steps. Chaining the `SampleDataForSplitPoints`, `SplitTable` and `AddElementsFromHdfs` operations together should work. It would be useful to create one operation which runs all of these.

title: Removal of properties using an iterator
body: It should be possible to specify that certain properties are not required in the results of a query, and have an iterator filter them out. If complex properties such as a HyperLogLogPlus are not required then removing them early on in the iterator stack will significantly reduce the amount of serialisation, deserialisation and aggregation that later iterators have to perform. It will also reduce the amount of data that needs to be transferred from tablet servers to the client.

title: Build fails with Accumulo 1.7.*
body:
Accumulo versions 1.6.\* and 1.7.\* should both be supported by Gaffer. Currently, the build (of the develop branch) fails if the version of Accumulo is set to 1.7.2 in the master pom. This is because one of the dependencies used by BatchScannerElementInputFormat depends on Accumulo 1.6 and uses classes that are not present in 1.7.

A short-term fix is to remove the InputFormat that causes the problem, and remove the dependencies it needs.

Accumulo 1.7 and later contains functionality to cause the same effect as BatchScannerElementInputFormat, so this input format should just be removed.

title: Add Instance Name to Mock Accumulo Store

title: InputFormat for Accumulo store
body: Create an InputFormat to allow MapReduce or Spark jobs to be run against an Accumulo store. This is an initial step towards allowing Spark to consume Gaffer data stored in Accumulo.

title: Locality groups in Accumulo store
body:
Accumulo's locality groups could be used so that queries that only require certain groups do not have to scan other groups (see http://accumulo.apache.org/1.7/accumulo_user_manual#_locality_groups). This is very natural with the current approach of storing the group in the column family, as a locality group is just a set of column families.

A sensible default option might be for different groups to be stored in different locality groups. This should speed up scans which require only a subset of the groups. Once locality groups are enabled, Accumulo will automatically take advantage of them when the `fetchColumnFamilies` method is called (which is already used in Gaffer).

title: Serialisation of properties in Value in Accumulo store
body: In the Accumulo store, properties that go in the Value are serialised by adding the properties to a MapWritable and then converting that to bytes. This serialises the number of properties, then the first property name, and the first property value, then the second property and second value, etc. Storing the property names is wasteful of storage, and as they are specified in the schema is unnecessary. It would take less storage to write out the properties in a defined order (either the order they are specified in the schema, or in alphabetical order), with a list of their serialised sizes in bytes. The advantage of the current approach is that it potentially makes it easier to allow schemas to evolve on an existing table. So this should be optional for the Accumulo store.

title: Same groups for Entities and Edges
body:
Currently, the same groups are not allowed to be used in Entities and Edges - if they are a message of "Groups must not be shared between Entity definitions and Edge definitions" is produced and then a `SchemaException` is thrown.

A very common use-case is to have a graph with say Edges with a group of "red", edges with a group of "blue", and then to have Entities with the same groups which contain the corresponding properties. E.g. the red edges have a count statistic, and each end of the edge has a red Entity associated with it which also contains a count (which is the count aggregated from all the red edges that that vertex is involved in). Similarly the blue edges might have a frequency map property, and there would also be blue vertices with that property that aggregate over associated edges.

It seems wrong to force the user to have a group of "EntityRed" for the Entities and "EdgeRed" for the Edges.

Is there a good reason for this restriction?

title: Missing Inputs/Outputs annotations
body: If a function is written which has a missing `Inputs` or `Outputs` annotation, then an Error with message "All consumer function classes must have inputs defined using the 'Inputs' annotation on the class." is thrown. This error does not say what class is causing the problem, nor does the stack trace. The error message should include the name of the class that is causing the problem.

title: Default serialisers
body:
If the user does not provide a serialiser for a property, then Java serialisation is used if possible. New users of the framework frequently do not specify serialisers and so unknowingly use Java serialisation, which was never intended to be used (and even in test cases such as the MockAccumuloStore can cause problems, for example range scans not working correctly).

Gaffer should automatically use good serialisers for common properties, e.g. short, int, long, float, double, String, Date, HyperLogLogPlus. The expert user can override these if required.

title: Warn when an Accumulo store is initialised against an existing non-Gaffer table
body:
If a user manually creates an Accumulo table (without adding Gaffer's iterators), and then creates a graph using store properties containing that table name, then the Accumulo initialise method will correctly notice that the table exists and not reinitialise it. This means that as far as Gaffer is concerned the table was created correctly, but actually it is just an empty table with no iterators.

This has caused confusion with some users as they manually create the table, then create the graph, then add data and notice that no aggregation is happening, which is then reported as a bug or a misconfiguration.

It's not clear what they best way to deal with this is. Options:
- If the table is already present the `ensureTableExists` method in `TableUtils` should log this, and say something like "Table X already exists. For correct operation it must have been created using Gaffer code."
- When creating a graph using a store that already exists, is there any way to check that this store is a Gaffer store, rather than just an empty Accumulo table?

title: gh-227 - change resource stream loader to use google reflections
Retrieval of domain objects through REST API
body:
Currently, the default return types of most of the operations which can be carried out against a graph are something along the lines of Iterable<? extends Element>.

I have a use case where I want to be able to consume domain objects (i.e. those which I have written object generators for) directly from the REST API - is this something that could be supported?

Currently I am having to use the doOperation endpoint exclusively and add the domain object generation as a step at the end of an operation chain. Ideally, I'd like to make no assumptions about the data model (or the available generator classes) in the applications which I am writing to consume the graph.

title: Improve logging in Accumulo table creation

The current logging only specifies the iterators that are being added and does not specify the name of the table. The TABLE_FILE_REPLICATION property should also be logged.

title: Gh 193 docker
Create docker image of gaffer rest api
Specification of aggregation logic
body:
Gaffer has the concept of aggregation. There are two types: persistent and query time. Technically though, Gaffer does not perform aggregation, it performs a reduce function: a group-by followed by an aggregation.

Currently, in the Accumulo store, aggregation is specified by specifying aggregators for some / all of the properties. The group-by function is not specified explicitly. It is specified implicitly by the choices the user makes about where properties go in Accumulo's key and value.

There are a few problems with this approach:
- It is too easy to get wrong.
- The concepts of an Accumulo key and a group-by key for the aggregation are confused.
- If a store that has no concept of a key is used, or if Accumulo is used in a different way, then there is no mechanism to specify the group-by function.
- The writer of the schema has to have knowledge of internal Accumulo concepts like column qualifier, visibility and value.

It would be better to specify, on a per-group basis, the desired group-by logic. For example, suppose an edge of group G has the following properties: time window, visibility, count. The user wants persistent aggregation to happen over time window and visibility, e.g. suppose the following edges are inserted:
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=public, count=1
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=private, count=1
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=public, count=2

The the user wants the public visibility edges to be merged so that the database should contain:
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=private, count=1
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=public, count=3

To specify this behaviour, the following properties are needed:
- property=count:
  - type=int
  - aggregator=sum
  - aggregationkeys=timewindow,visibility

The Accumulo store should be able to decide where to store the three properties based on this specification (in practice it might be necessary for the same aggregation keys to be specified for all the properties within a group, but this can be checked at store creation time).

Now consider query-time aggregation and suppose the graph contains:
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=private, count=1
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=public, count=2
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160102-03, visibility=private, count=5
- A->B of group G with timewindow=20160103-04, visibility=public, count=8
- A->C of group G with timewindow=20160107-08, visibility=private, count=100

There are multiple types of query-time aggregation that the user might want to be performed when A is queried for, e.g.
- (1) Aggregate timewindow, visibility and count to get:
  - A->B of group G with timewindow=201601-04, visibility=private&public, count=16
  - A->C of group G with timewindow=20160107-08, visibility=private, count=100
- (2) Aggregate visibility and count to get:
  - A->B of group G with timewindow=20160101-02, visibility=private&public, count=3
  - A->B of group G with timewindow=20160102-03, visibility=private, count=5
  - A->B of group G with timewindow=20160103-04, visibility=public, count=8
  - A->C of group G with timewindow=20160107-08, visibility=private, count=100
- (3) Aggregate destination, timewindow, visibility and count to get:
  - A->{B,C} of group G with timewindow=20160101-08, visibility=private&public, count=116

What is needed to specify these different behaviours?
- Case (1): Aggregate functions for timewindow, visibility and count. Aggregation keys of edge and group.
- Case (2): Aggregate functions for visibility and count. Aggregation keys of edge, group and timewindow.
- Case (3): Aggregate functions for vertex, timewindow, visibility and count. Aggregation key of group.

In practice, the types of aggregation that can be performed are limited by the capabilities of the store. In the case of Accumulo, one wants to limit the amount of data cached in the tablet server as the aggregation is performed. For example, it is unlikely to be sensible to aggregate over destination, timewindow, visibility but not count - that would require caching an edge for each distinct count, and nothing can be output until all of A's edges have been read. This could mean caching millions of edges and would put strain on the tablet server.

Currently the view is not flexible enough to allow these different types of group-by logic to be specified, and the store cannot specify which types it supports and which it doesn't. This has already led to confusion about the natural meaning of "aggregation" in range scans.

Again, the meaning of aggregation is not clearly defined enough.

Ordering of properties:

In an Accumulo store, the natural way to implement persistent aggregation is to put the grouping keys in the column qualifier and the values to be aggregated in the value. The ordering of the properties in the column qualifier effects the efficiency of some queries. For example, suppose that timewindow and visibility are in the column qualifier and the user queries for the edge A->B with a filter saying that only timewindow 20160102-03 is required. If the timewindow is the first property in the column qualifier then the range scan set up to find everything about edges A->B can skip all other timewindows. If the filter says that all timewindows are required but only one visibility is required then this has to be done by a filtering iterator. Currently the Accumulo store is not smart enough to spot this opportunity and optimise this query. This is really a different issue to the above aggregation issues but it is mentioned here because it has been said that allowing the user to specify in the schema where properties go in Accumulo's key-values allows these sort of optimisations later. This may be true, but again there is no need to specify rowkeys, column qualifier, etc - it is the ordering of the properties in the key that matters.

There is a similar issue with ordering of properties in the value - if the user specifies that in the properties in the graph elements that they receive back from a query they only want to see the count property and not the other properties that are being aggregated, then if the count property is first in the value that can be deserialised and the rest of the value skipped (if there are multiple properties including complex ones such as bitmaps then avoiding the deserialisation cost of these could be significant). Again, this means that the ordering of properties could be important. The store could advertise that ordering properties in certain ways allows it to perform certain optimisations. But again there should be no need to specify which part of the Accumulo key and value.

title: Invalid Javadoc in gaffer.operation.impl.Validate
body:
The JavaDoc at the top of `gaffer.operation.impl.Validate` contains `{@link gaffer.store.schema.Schema}`. This isn't valid as `Validate` is in the `operation` module which doesn't have a dependency on the `store` module which is where `Schema` is defined. This means that building the JavaDoc with Java 8 fails.

Adding a dependency on the `store` module from the `operation` module isn't allowed as it introduces a cyclic dependency.

title: Summarising over RowID's in accumulo
body:
We should add the ability to summarise over rowID's in a range query that will aggregate those values over the range provided grouped by Column Family 

I.e in a Graph of Edge's 
A-B GROUP 1 Count 6 
A-B GROUP 2 Count 4 
A-C GROUP 1 Count 1

With the summarise option on, a range query of A-C would return 2 edges.
One (A-B+A-C) with a count of 7 
And one A-B with a count of 4.

title: Serialisers and aggregators for sketches from the Data Sketches library
body: Yahoo's Data Sketches library (https://github.com/DataSketches/sketches-core) contains many useful sketches. We should provide serialisers and aggregators for these.

title: Implement serialisers and aggregators for more sketches from the stream-lib library
body: Gaffer provides a serialiser and an aggregator for the HyperLogLogPlus sketch from the stream-lib library. That library contains other useful sketches such as Count Min Sketch. Serialisers and aggregators should be provided for those. Specifically, they should be written for: CountMinSketch, QDigest, TDigest.

title: Create ComparableMin aggregator
body: Common aggregation methods for Dates are to take the earliest or the latest. Gaffer should provide aggregators that can be used for this. ComparableMax can be used to take the latest Date. There is no ComparableMin - one should be implemented.

title: Add alternate Date serialiser
body: The provided Date serialisation extracts the long timestamp from the Date, converts that to a string and then converts that to a byte array. A RawDateSerialiser should be provided which serialises the long from the Date using a similar method to RawLongSerialiser.

title: Serialisation for Ints and Longs
body: Currently there are 2 serialisations for Ints and for Longs. One is slow because it converts the int to a String and converts that to a byte array but has the advantage of only needing 1 byte to serialise some small values; the other is likely quicker but always uses 4 bytes. In many cases, when ints are stored they are mostly very small. The approach of Hadoop's VIntWritable should be (almost) as quick as the latter and as compact as the former. So suggest adding an implementation based on this. To avoid introducing a dependency on Hadoop in the serialisation library, suggest just copying the code from Hadoop, and acknowledging it in the NOTICES file.

For ticket gh-247 and others in the future we need to pass context between execution of operations. Currently we just pass a user object between operations, but it would be more flexible to pass a context object that contains the user and other information such as a cache (this may change in gh-247 to export configuration).

The cache operations should then be handled with operation handlers instead of having the logic directly in the store class.
